DIV1.P: A COMEDY, IN FIVE ACTS; AS IT IS PERFORMED AT THE THEATRE-ROYAL, IN DRURY-LANE.
LONDON▪ PRINTED FOR T. BECKET, ADELPHI, STRAND.

DIV1.HEAD: PREFACE.
DIV1.P: THIS Comedy having abided the decision of the public, having undergone the strictures of criticism, and, notwithstanding its numerous errors, having fortunately met with general approbation, the author hopes he may, in conjunction with other disposers of the drama, be indulged with a few re∣marks of his own.

The great objection to this play has been the want of plot, an objection which the author will not pre∣tend to dispute; but then he begs it may be consi∣dered, that his chief aim in writing was to draw a lively picture of the manners of high life, characte∣rised by an easy indifference to the vissicitudes of fortune, and a kind of indolent acceptance of every fashionable enjoyment; he therefore imagined an in∣tricacy of plot would ill accord with the delineation of personages, who would not themselves undergo the fatigue of engaging in a multiplicity of bnsiness, to promote either their dearest interests, or their fondest pleasures. To supply this defect, the author has endeavoured to support, through five acts, a pleasant laughable dialogue, heightened by stage situ∣ation; an undertaking, in his opinion, full as diffi∣cult as the invention of fable. How far he has suc∣ceeded, is now submitted to the candid consideration of the reader.
Having said thus much concerning the reception of the play before the curtain, it may be necessary to mention the treatment it has met with behind.

Mr. Sheridan, it must be confessed, has taken away several witty things from this comedy, which proba∣bly would have had a striking and very violent effect; but should he, in his great dearth of genius, ever venture to introduce them in any future production
of his own, and the audience should not immediate∣ly perceive the difference, the original author will cer∣tainly put in his claim to all the merit they possess.

But to be serious—To the proprietors of the thea∣tre all thanks are due for their care, attention, and liberality in getting up this play; and to Mr. Lin∣ley in particular, for his politeness in offering, and his skill in composing, the music introduced in the third act.

Of the performers, for their diligence and their un∣rivalled talents, the author cannot say enough; like Sir Andrew Acorn, in the comedy, it is impossible for him to do them justice, and, therefore, he won't undertake it.

Mrs. Abington's elegant deportment, her perfect knowledge of polished life, the graceful ease and na∣tural sprightliness with which she plays the part of Lady Rentless, can only be equalled by the chearful∣ness and affability with which she accepted it.
Mr. King's excellence may not be dwelt upon, lest from the recollection of Puff, in the Critic, the real tribute of applause might force an improper smile.

Mr. Parsons—but it is impossible to be serious about him—from the moment he appears on the stage to the end of the piece, he neither walks, looks, or speaks, without calling forth the risibility of the audience; the part may have some merit, but with such support, that character must be poorly drawn indeed that would not please.

Mr. Palmer, Mr. Baddeley, and the rest of the performers, are equally intitled to the gratitude of the author, but for the critic reason, hinted at above, he will not venture to enlarge further on their com∣mendation.

LG.L: WHAT a strange title this is—Dissipation!—
Ideal whim!—the author's wild creation!
In this romantic, sentimental age,
Exists there such a folly—off the stage?
The satire's false—Our bard has wander'd much—
We're wise and prudent, as our friends—the Dutch.
Look to our careful Commons, frugal Lords;
No waste there—Yes—some little waste—of words.
But more there are, who thrifty rhetoric shew,
The close, mum eloquence of—Aye and No:
They mark Don Whiskerandos to a letter,
"And if it must, the less is said, the better."
See too his Grace amid New-market Sirs,
That deep fraternity of boots and spurs!
View him full dress'd—half flannel and half leather,
Up to twelve stone—or sweated to a feather.
In no profusion is he known to sin;
He takes fair pains—and sometimes more—to win;
But should the faithful dice for once run cross,
Not he—"my little Premium paysh de losh."
No falling trees or ruin'd farms deplore him,
His sires, good men! have made all smooth before him.
In gentler bosoms does this folly reign!
First, at Salt Hill, of all the hunting train,
Behold the broad brim'd Dian of the day,
Top five-bar gates, and shew the field the way?
"Sure," cries some bridling dame, for scandal ready,
"These leaps are not so prudent in a lady.
"No, Ma'am! why not?—Grant Miss should have a fall,
"A friendly settlement will cover all."
In short, the rage of Dissipation's o'er;
The very clubs have voted it a—bore.
Their paper currency is under par;
For gold they mutiny—or cut the war.
Nay, tho' a grave divine's convenient plan,
Invites to take some twenty wives a man,
The prudent soul rejects the blessings sent him▪
And finds—I hear at least—one wife content him.
But should our headstrong bard have dar'd to-night,
In bold contempt of precedent, to write
Five comic acts, with mournful scenes unblest,
And only entertaining at the best,
To draw from rakes reform'd no—moral speeches—
No decent sentiments from Miss—in breeches—
In short, should he have penn'd a laughing play,
And rashly thrown some idle wit away,
Pray, gentlemen—I beg no hesitation—
Damn him! and shew you hate all Dissipation.
FASHION's the word—again at her command
To mark her sovereign sway I take my stand,
All ranks alike adore my potent queen
From proud St. James's Square, to Bethnal-Green,
The titled dame not more her head can toss
Than the ship captain's wife, at Ratcliff-Cross,
Nor more contemptuous frowns the birth-night belle
Than does the drawn-up Miss, of Clerkenwell;
All would be fine, the difference only—what?
Her Grace thinks this genteel, and Madam that.
The fair of high descent and noble blood
Esteems it vulgar to be understood,
Proud of the worth her ancestors bequeath her
She thinks the gifts of Nature far beneath her
Rejects low talents that disgrace her station;
And scorns the meanness of articulation.
In a half whisper thus, our minds we tell
How'ch you do!—'t see you—'p you're very well.
Sir John, an urchin just emerg'd from school,
Disdains with Hoyden girls, to play the fool.
"O curse the women all! but those who play
"How do you like my buckles? Made by Gray."
"Dancing's a bore—and love sad stuff at best is,
"Damn it, I hate all dancing, but the Vestris."
In humbler life still fashion is the word
Full as fantastic and yet more absurd.
The great fat wife of some great fat shopkeeper
Deep in court-mourning grey, and somewhat deeper,
Cramm'd in a Hackney-coach at Cutler's Hall
Takes three coarse misses to the Mile-end ball;
Then, waddling up the room roars out to spouse
"Here's no good company at all, I vows,"
And there's Miss Pumpkin, dizen'd out in red,
Why don't you knows? Knows what? Why knows who's dead.
Dead! Lord have mercy, who? Our great third cousin
Adolphus-Wolfus-Peter Herring Bussen."
Thus thro' the world 'tis still our constant aim
To ape the follies we affect to blame,
But hold—methinks improvidently wise
We rashly censure what we ought to prize,
Ladies, for us exert this darling passion
Do, ton it here, and make this play the fashion.

SP.SPEAKER: COQUIN.
SP.P: AH, Maistre Trusty, vel met, vere be you going so fast?

SP.SPEAKER: TRUSTY.
SP.P: Business, business, must be minded, Monsieur, Coq—Coq—what the Devil is your hard name? I always forget it.

SP.SPEAKER: COQUIN.
SP.P: Oh, fidon, Maistre Trusty! vat, forget your ver good friend, Oh, for shame!

SP.SPEAKER: TRUSTY.
SP.P: Forgive me, Monsieur. You still live with my Lord Rentless, I suppose. What capacity are you now in?

SP.SPEAKER: COQUIN.
SP.P: Capacité, ma foi; I cannot answer dat question. Me be ver ready to do any ting at all.

SP.SPEAKER: TRUSTY.
SP.P: Or nothing at all, just at happens.

SP.SPEAKER: COQUIN.
SP.P: Ha! ha! ha! you be one drole negotiant, Maistre Trusty, tho' en verité de famille, no know wat to call me.

SP.SPEAKER: TRUSTY.
SP.P: That's a pity, indeed. I think I could tell them. [Aside.

SP.SPEAKER: COQUIN.
SP.P: Oh! I recollect, de parlement d'Angleterre, have in∣vent one title exprès, and I am charge in de tax bill, as Maitre d'Hotel to my Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: TRUSTY.
SP.P: Upon my word, our nobility are much oblig'd to the parliament for taking the trouble to distinguish their ser∣vants: but if I mistake not, this means master of the house, and that's a strange employment surely for a French—you understand me, in the service of an English peer.

SP.SPEAKER: COQIN.
SP.P: Pardonez moi, my Lor love de jeu, de quinze, deha∣zard, he hate account, he love bon vivant, good eat, good drink, he hate de tought, de reflection; in a word, he love plaisir, and he hate trouble, so he give it up to me, dat's all; he love de prett girl, and he—

SP.SPEAKER: TRUSTY.
SP.P: And he hates his wife: does he give her up too?

SP.SPEAKER: COQUIN.
SP.P: Oh, que non! he love dem both ma foi; but your master de Alderman, do just de same tin, he leave to you de commerce, no more preserve mango, and sweet oil for de customer, 'tis all blood and wounds for de foe.

SP.SPEAKER: TRUSTY.
SP.P: Aye, times are sadly changed; formerly, indeed, a day in the artillery ground once a year, and a review of the orange regiment, with a march to dinner, was quite suf∣ficient for a sober citizen; but now my master is stark staring mad, and has been lock'd up three hours a day for these two months past, to learn to salute; at his years to learn to salute.

SP.SPEAKER: COQUIN.
SP.P: Certainement! never too late for dat!

SP.SPEAKER: TRUSTY.
SP.P: And worse still, since your lord has thought proper to appoint him to a light infantry company in his own regi∣ment; he has totally discarded his sober snuff-colour'd frock, grey silk stockings, and smooth powder'd bob, for a short jacket, loose boots, and a little helmet.

SP.SPEAKER: COQUIN.
SP.P: What, would you not have de good citizen defend his country?

SP.SPEAKER: TRUSTY.
SP.P: Undoubtedly, at a proper time of life, nothing can be more honourable or praiseworthy; but I would not have my old master run about making anticks, when he should be thinking only of making his will. Then Miss Maria—

SP.SPEAKER: COQUIN.
SP.P: Mademoiselle Maria, ver sweet creature, vat of her?

SP.SPEAKER: TRUSTY.
SP.P: Why, she's always in regimentals too, prancing about the streets on horseback, or firing pistols at our goods in the shop; I dare say she has shot a dozen red-herrings thro' the head within these ten days.

SP.SPEAKER: COQUIN.
SP.P: Ah! la jolie militaire!

SP.SPEAKER: TRUSTY.
SP.P: But I must be gone, so I wish you a good morning.

SP.SPEAKER: COQUIN.
SP.P: Attendez! Will you do me de faveur to give one little card des compliments to Mademoiselle Maria?

SP.SPEAKER: TRUSTY.
SP.P: That's not quite in my way, Monsieur!

SP.SPEAKER: COQUIN.
SP.P: Oh, fidon! no harm, upon my vord.

SP.SPEAKER: TRUSTY▪
SP.P: Well, give it me, I'll save you the trouble, as you seem to be so hard work'd. Your servant, good Mr. Co∣quin. What a hypocritical French rascal. [Aside.] Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: COQUIN.
SP.P: Adieu, mon cher ami, my ver dear friend. Quel vul∣gaire Englis brute! [Aside.] [Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: MISS.
SP.P: Lord, Winney! I never saw any thing so aukward in my life. You don't know how to put in a cockade.

SP.SPEAKER: WINNI.
SP.P: Dear-a-me, Miss, how should I? Your good mamma never worse such a thing in her life.

SP.SPEAKER: MISS.
SP.P: What of that? Every body now is dress'd a la militar; does not Mrs. Squab, the brewer's wife, go about in a scarlet uniform? and don't Miss what's her name, the what d'ye call 'em's daughter, appear every where in re∣gimentals?

SP.SPEAKER: WINNI.
SP.P: More shame for them. My poor old mistress used to say, Let every woman look like one.

SP.SPEAKER: MISS.
SP.P: What care I what she said. You are always plaguing me with old sayings of my mamma's; I am sure you make one sorry one ever had any mother at all; but it could n't be helpt! and as to dress, my good mamma, as you call her, knew no more of it than you do.

SP.SPEAKER: WINNI.
SP.P: Dear-a-me, Miss, I am surprised at you! My good old lady not a judge of dress! Well, I shall never forget her! with her neat white cotton stockings; brown sil gown pleated in the back; black callimanco petticoat; clean muslin apron, nicely folded; handkerchief up to her chin, and cap tied under it—Oh! she was a model for the gentry of Cheapside.

SP.SPEAKER: MISS.
SP.P: Come, prithee, lay aside your old fashion'd notions, and be a little more modern; you must now prepare for the camp; I have order'd you a plain regimental on purpose.

SP.SPEAKER: WINNI.
SP.P: O Miss! I at the camp! Why I have no more heart than a mouse. Think what a figure I should make in a plain regimental; indeed, I beg pardon, but I hope you don't think of going there.

SP.SPEAKER: MISS.
SP.P: Indeed but I do. Is not Mrs. Twist, the man's mercer, and Madam Tug, the female dentist, and the three Miss Firkins gone to the camp, all to expose themselves for the sake of their country? Besides, is not my father going to camp, and Lord Rentless going to camp, though one of the finest men about town?

SP.SPEAKER: WINNI.
SP.P: Alack-a-day! Lord Rentless has turned my poor master's brain, he has been the ruin of him; and if you don't take care, Miss, I know what.

SP.SPEAKER: MISS
SP.P: Pooh! What do you know?

SP.SPEAKER: WINNI.
SP.P: Why, that he'll be the ruin of you, that's all. Indeed, Miss, I'm afraid he's a bad man.

SP.SPEAKER: MISS.
SP.P: Lord, Winney! how should you know any thing about a man?

SP.SPEAKER: SERVANT.
SP.P: Ma'am, Mr. Trusty desired me to present you this letter, he had it from my Lord Rentless's gentleman.

SP.SPEAKER: MISS.
SP.P:
Let me see it. There, you may go. [Exit SERVANT. [Reads.] “Lady Rentless gives the world a breakfast
to-morrow morning at two—” But what's this by it∣self? “I hope, my dear Miss Uniform▪ will favour me with her company; I have something tender to whisper to her. For ceremony's sake ask the old Alderman.”

DIV2.P: Oh, how delightfully he writes! [Aside.] Winney, you must step into my father's room, and tell him, I engage him to breakfast with Lord Rentless to-morrow at two o'clock precisely.

SP.SPEAKER: WINNI.
SP.P: Breakfast at two o'clock! Lord help us! Such an in∣vitation would have starved my poor old mistress. [Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: MISS.
SP.P: What a charming man is his Lordship! Such an air of the Ton, such a manner, and pays me so much respect. Then how it will mortify all the little people to see me attended by his Lordship to camp; and then to be the wonder of all the military gentlemen, whilst I practice my exercise—to the right—to the left—march—present—fire!—"Oh, what a charming thing's a battle!"

DIV2.HEAD: SCENE III.
DIV2.STAGE: Discovers an Oil-man's Shop, various Jars and Implements of Trade, Military Accoutrements amongst them; ALDER∣MAN UNIFORM in the Front; People waiting behind; a Tailor and a Cap-maker with him.

SP.SPEAKER: ALDERMAN.
SP.P: Well, Mr. Frontispiece, how do I look, hah? This tail has a curious effect on the top of one's head, hah!

SP.SPEAKER: FRONTISPIECE.
SP.P: The cap is extremely becoming, and as light as if made of paper.

SP.SPEAKER: ALDERMAN.
SP.P: Well, Mr. Cut'em, this jacket is quite the thing, is it not?

SP.SPEAKER: CUT'EM.
SP.P: Made from Sir Jeffery Swift's own pattern.

SP.SPEAKER: ALDERMAN.
SP.P: Piquet me, if it is not horribly genteel; and then cut to the quick, not an inch of cloth more than is necessary.

SP.SPEAKER: CUT'EM.
SP.P: Calculated to accommodate the speed.

SP.SPEAKER: ALDERMAN.
SP.P: Speed! Stop my pay, if there's any standing still while one has it on. [Runs across the stage.] And then this sword is so devilish handy under one's arm.

SP.SPEAKER: FRONTISPIECE.
SP.P: Amazing, indeed! I never saw a gentleman so active at your time of life.

SP.SPEAKER: ALDERMAN.
SP.P: Practice makes perfect, as we say in the city. Why I never knew how to use my legs before; but, gentle∣men, I shan't want you any more at present. Gentle∣men, your most obedient. [Saluting with his hand up to his cap.] [Exeunt Frontispiece and Cut'em.
To the Shopman.] Well, Thomas, any fresh orders to day, hey?

SP.SPEAKER: SHOPMAN.
SP.P: Just received one from Deputy Blubber, for a larg parcel of pickles. He says, last turned out but bad.

SP.SPEAKER: ALDERMAN.
SP.P: Send me to the drill, if he knows any thing about the matter, I never had a finer parcel in my life.

SP.SPEAKER: TRADESMAN.
SP.P: Sir, I am sorry to inform you, but since you have taken up this nonsense business, I have not had an order sent to my shop as it should be.

SP.SPEAKER: ALDERMAN.
SP.P: Tie me to the halberds, but you must be mistaken▪ friend.

SP.SPEAKER: TRADESMAN.
SP.P: Tie me to the halberds, but I am not mistaken, friend. The last parcel of dried tongues came full of gun-shot wounds. Hang me, if I think your worship knows what you are about.

SP.SPEAKER: ALDERMAN.
SP.P: Impossible! but I'll shew you. Hand down the ledger; there, friend, read. [Gives it him.

SP.SPEAKER: TRADESMAN.
SP.P: [Reads.] “July 12th. Sent out a party to mend the roads.” There, [Throws down the book.] didn't I say as how you didn't know what you was about? Mend the roads, indeed! Odsheart, but I believe your worship's in the road to ruin. So your worship's servant. [Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: ALDERMAN.
SP.P: [Picking up the book.] Drum me out of the regiment, but this is the orderly book. Why, Thomas, how could you be such a blockhead?

SP.SPEAKER: SHOPMAN.
SP.P: Indeed, Sir, there's such a mixture, it's impossible to know one thing from another.

DIV2.STAGE: Enter a PORTER with a Jar.

SP.SPEAKER: PORTER.
SP.P: Sir, Master Goose desires to have this jar filled with cucumbers.

SP.SPEAKER: ALDERMAN.
SP.P: The tailor shall be suited. Give me the pen.

DIV2.STAGE: Enter a SERVANT on the other side.

SP.SPEAKER: SERVANT.
SP.P: Sir, the serjeant waits to teach you to salute.

SP.SPEAKER: ALDERMAN.
SP.P: That's right. [Salutes about the stage with the pen in his hand.] May I never handle a firelock, if I don't do it with a good grace.

SP.SPEAKER: SERVANT
SP.P: Will you take a lesson now, Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: ALDERMAN.
SP.P: No!

SP.SPEAKER: PORTER
SP.P: When shall I have the pickles?

SP.SPEAKER: ALDERMAN.
SP.P: Hey!

SP.SPEAKER: SERVANT.
SP.P: He begs to know when you will, Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: ALDERMAN.
SP.P: Not till to-morrow.

SP.SPEAKER: PORTER,
SP.P: No! then, indeed, I have something else to do. [Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: SERVANT,
SP.P: And so ought other people, in my mind. [Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: SHOPMAN.
SP.P: Sir, I had forgot. Here's a letter from the sutler at Dartford to desire the anchovies and train oil may be sent down immediately. Now, I was thinking that they might go along with your camp equipage.

SP.SPEAKER: ALDERMAN.
SP.P: Why, zounds! would you have me disgrace the whole corps! Do you want to suffocate the army? Send me to the Savoy, if I ever heard such a thing in my life. Anchovies and train oil with camp equipage! Why, I shall be known by my scent, pursued like a drag, and hunted down by my own regiment.

SP.SPEAKER: EPHRAIM.
SP.P: Mashter Alderman, your servant. I shost made a pashover from the Shinagog, because I wash in haste to tell you the newsh.

SP.SPEAKER: ALDERMAN.
SP.P: News, Ephraim! What news?

SP.SPEAKER: EPHRAIM.
SP.P: Great newsh, indeed! They are all landed.

SP.SPEAKER: ALDERMAN.
SP.P: Landed! Impossible!

SP.SPEAKER: EPHRAIM.
SP.P: No, tish very true; and as fine a cargo ash ever I shee'd in my life.

SP.SPEAKER: ALDERMAN.
SP.P: Cargo! Zounds! I thought you had meant the French.

SP.SPEAKER: EPHRAIM.
SP.P: French! Marshy upon us! Why it ish the cots from Newfoundland dat ish arife; all sweet and fresh as the shee water itself.

SP.SPEAKER: ALDERMAN.
SP.P: [Mocking him.] Rot your shee water.

SP.SPEAKER: EPHRAIM.
SP.P: God forbids!

SP.SPEAKER: ALDERMAN.
SP.P: Cut me up but I was ready for them—But no matter; down, my heroic spirit. Commerce will be heard; tho' may I never wear a gaiter, if it isn't a vulgar employ∣ment.

SP.SPEAKER: EPHRAIM.
SP.P: Now, I differs from you, Maishter Uniform. I wash always think nothing vulgar that wash profitable.

SP.SPEAKER: ALDERMAN.
SP.P: Aye; these notions may do at Bear Key, but they would be scouted on the parade. Why don't you en∣deavour to push yourself a little into genteel life.

SP.SPEAKER: EPHRAIM.
SP.P: Indeed, I wash push a great deal; and am forced to be very hard with the nobility and young men of fashion.

SP.SPEAKER: ALDERMAN.
SP.P: Stop my pay, but I believe they are hard pushed. However, your persuasion prevents you from being ad∣mitted into the line, as we say.

SP.SPEAKER: EPHRAIM.
SP.P: Not at all. I never wash know any line that the money bags could not rub out.

SP.SPEAKER: ALDERMAN.
SP.P: Why, your face, indeed, might be white-washed; but in the army we are a little particular about figure. [Surveying his own, and walking about.]

SP.SPEAKER: EPHRAIM.
SP.P: Oh! I believe there ish no objection to my person. [Looking at it.] De ladies find no fault met dat.

SP.SPEAKER: ALDERMAN.
SP.P: The ladies! ha! ha! Impossible!

SP.SPEAKER: EPHRAIM.
SP.P: What ish impossible! There ish your friend Lady Rentless, that I wash more intimate with than you are, Maisher Alderman, for all you are my Lord's captain.

SP.SPEAKER: ALDERMAN.
SP.P: You intimate with my Lady! Why, she's the very pink of the mode; makes fashions for the whole town; gives entertainments to the whole town; sits up all night. Why, drill me, but she's a diamond of the first water.

SP.SPEAKER: EPHRAIM.
SP.P: Aye; I love the diamond of the first water, and have got the possession of most of them.

SP.SPEAKER: ALDERMAN.
SP.P: You!

SP.SPEAKER: EPHRAIM.
SP.P: Yes; my Lorsh was entrusht me with my Ladysh jewel, and she is kept in the dark.

SP.SPEAKER: ALDERMAN.
SP.P: Very kind, indeed!

SP.SPEAKER: EPHRAIM.
SP.P: I wash forced though to advansh a great deal.

SP.SPEAKER: ALDERMAN.
SP.P: That's a new way, little Ephy, of making advance to the ladies.

SP.SPEAKER: EPHRAIM.
SP.P: Yesh, but I fancy it is the shuresht after all. If the husband is so extravagant to put his wife's trinkets into my hands, and she is eager to get them out again; why, then you knowsh—But I never destroysh any ladysh reputation.

SP.SPEAKER: ALDERMAN.
SP.P: I believe not. The world, indeed, might suspect the smart, well-dressed gentlemen of the army; but—

SP.SPEAKER: EPHRAIM.
SP.P: O fyesh! What, praise yourself! I shan't stay to hear that; though I thinksh that there are peoplesh who say nothing, that could be full as civil as the military.

SP.SPEAKER: ALDERMAN.
SP.P: Dragoon me, old Laradore, I hope you don't mean to set up at your time of life in the business of love∣making.

SP.SPEAKER: EPHRAIM.
SP.P: And if I doesh, young Uniform, I shan't become your apprentish.

SP.SPEAKER: ALDERMAN.
SP.P: Well, Mr. Ephraim Narcissus of Duke's Place, I submit to your modesty.

SP.SPEAKER: EPHRAIM.
SP.P: And, Mr. Alderman Soldier from Fishmonger's Hall, I knock under to your assurance. [Exeunt severally.

DIV2.HEAD: ACT II. SCENE I.
DIV2.STAGE: Variety of Servants playing at Hazard, others at Brag.

SP.SPEAKER: COACHMAN.
SP.P: WELL, my boys, now for your silver; now for it, [Shaking the Box.] Seven's the main, seven.

SP.SPEAKER: FOOTMAN.
SP.P: Nick, was ever such luck? Why you have thrown in five hands running, master coachman.

SP.SPEAKER: COACHMAN.
SP.P: Drive away again, my boys; five's the main, five.

SP.SPEAKER: PORTER.
SP.P: Throws down his Wig.] There's my hat and wig.

SP.SPEAKER: POSTILLION.
SP.P: I lay the odds.

SP.SPEAKER: BAILIFF.
SP.P: Done, postilion, I take them.

SP.SPEAKER: POSTILION.
SP.P: No, hold hard there, Master Fleece'em; you gemmen are but slippery kind of folks: so I'm off.

SP.SPEAKER: BAILIF.
SP.P: Zounds, I don't understand what you mean.

SP.SPEAKER: POSTILION.
SP.P: Why then I'll tell you: I don't like to bet with a bailiff.

SP.SPEAKER: BAILIFF.
SP.P: Gentlemen, I appeal to you, whether this is proper usage, when I have the honour to be here on an execution in his Lordship's house.

SP.SPEAKER: FOOTMAN.
SP.P: O no, no! Come, Tom, beg Mr. Fleece'em's pardon; if my Lord is n't asham'd of him, why should we?

SP.SPEAKER: COACHMAN,
SP.P: Five to eight.

DIV2.P: Pray, coach'y, is my Lady to have the vis a vis to-day?

SP.SPEAKER: COACHMAN.
SP.P: Eight, as I'm alive; damn the vis a vis; what do you plague me for? Damn the vis a vis.

SP.SPEAKER: FOOTMAN.
SP.P: Thank you, Bob, you have turn'd his luck. Stay here and you shall be groom porter.

SP.SPEAKER: COQUIN.
SP.P: Hah! be gar, mi good boys; what at it so early, is no my Lord stirring?

SP.SPEAKER: FOOTMAN.
SP.P: Stirring! Why it's only one o'clock yet; who is the aster. Won't you throw, Coquy?

SP.SPEAKER: COQUIN.
SP.P: Yes, be gar, I will throw myself down, I am so tire. [Bell rings, all get up in confusion, pocketing Cards and Dice.

SP.SPEAKER: SERVANT.
SP.P: Ah! that's the devilish bell above stairs.

SP.SPEAKER: SERVANT,
SP.P: Unlucky! I would have bragged my whole fortune upon that hand.

SP.SPEAKER: COACHMAN,
SP.STAGE: going out and smocking his Whip.
SP.P: Zounds, how I should have cut them up!

SP.SPEAKER: COQUIN.
SP.P: Depechez vous, mon Dieu, how much I tire. [Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: FOOTMAN,
SP.P: Oh, curse your larum! Exeunt.

DIV2.HEAD: SCENE II.
DIV2.STAGE: A Passage leading to the Breakfast-Room, Servants carrying several things.—Bell rings again.

SP.SPEAKER: COQUIN.
SP.P: Here, take de chocolate for my Lady breakfast, and de Chronique, vid de Parliament Debate, for my Lord. Oh, I am so fatigue. Well, Monsieur Cook, wat have you got?

DIV2.P: Only the bill of fare, Mr. Coquin.

SP.SPEAKER: COQUIN.
SP.P: Voyons; soup, fish, remove—fricassée stew, pate with entreme—beef, veal, mutton, on de side table—ah peu de chose. Dis diné, Monsieur Cook, will not get you much credit.

SP.SPEAKER: COOK.
SP.P: No, then it will get my Lord some at least; for I don't believe there is a single article that is paid for.

SP.SPEAKER: COQUIN.
SP.P: Ah! ver comique, indeed. [Bell rings.] Allons depe∣hez. [Exeunt.

DIV2.HEAD: SCENE III.
DIV2.STAGE: Lord and Lady RENTLESS, and CHARLES, at Breakfast.

SP.SPEAKER: LADY.
SP.P: Well, really I am monstrously fatigued. These hours will absolutely be the death of one.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLES.
SP.P: Was your Ladyship at home later than usual last night?

SP.SPEAKER: LADY.
SP.P: Later! Oh, fie, Charles: I mean rising at this un∣reasonable time, before noon; sitting up, I believe, agrees with my constitution▪ I never feel myself half so chear∣ful [Yawning.] as when the world are in bed. But, my Lord, do you know you are growing absolutely domestic? My woman tells me, you were at home before two.

SP.SPEAKER: LORD.
SP.P: Very likely, but I was out of spirits last night myself.

SP.SPEAKER: LADY.
SP.P: What, then you had no play at Brookes?

SP.SPEAKER: LORD.
SP.P: Yes, a little chicken hazard; but we are all so poor at present, that except the Baronet there—what's his name?—that swears so much, a thousand pounds wou'd see out the whole room? Ah, this war has quite knock'd up hazard; it is a devilish distressing war for the country, that's certain.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLES.
SP.P: Your Lordship will grow a politician.

SP.SPEAKER: LORD.
SP.P: Why, when one has nothing else to do its amuzing enough. Pray, do I say any thing in the House yester∣day?

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLES,
SP.P: Yes, I see your Lordship has beeen speaking against the Budget.

SP.SPEAKER: LORD.
SP.P: Against the Budget! No, against it! O yes, yes, so I was; I did not recollect immediately; but you know its all the same thing with us.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLES.
SP.P: Really, my Lord!

SP.SPEAKER: LADY.
SP.P: Why, you grave creature, ha! ha! ha! are you going to be surprized, because a man of fashion forgets which side he took, or thinks politicks a mere matter of amuse∣ment?

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLES.
SP.P: Pardon me, my Lady; I had imagined, that a member of the British senate, did not give his vote, or speak his public sentiments merely for his amusement.

SP.SPEAKER: LORD.
SP.P: To be sure he does not; sometimes it is for the amuse∣ment of other people. But you are immensely ignorant, my dear Charles. Do you really suppose we give our∣selves the trouble to understand every subject we debate upon? Ha! ha! ha! some things, indeed, one can't help being familiar with, such as the national debt, or the ruin of one's country, or naturalizing a Jew, or—

SP.SPEAKER: LADY.
SP.P: Ay, or a Divorce Bill. A-propos, now we talk of di∣vorces, don't let us forget Charles's marriage.

SP.SPEAKER: LORD.
SP.P: True, I suppose the old Baronet will arrive soon, en-fa∣mille; upon my word this will be an immense good match for you, Charles, that's poz. Sir Andrew Acorn, tho' a sad country clown, to say the truth, has a very fine estate, and is of a most encouraging age for a father-in-law.

SP.SPEAKER: LADY.
SP.P: Yes, and Miss, tho' a mere rustic, with her head full of love and conjugal affection, and so on; yet I have no doubt, my Lord, when she has liv'd a little among us, she will soon be wean'd from her absurdities.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLES.
SP.P: Your Ladyship will excuse me, but I should not wish a wife of mine to think it an absurdity to love her hus∣band.

SP.SPEAKER: LORD.
SP.P: Why, who, my dear Charles, says any such thing? But, wou'd you have this wife of yours distracted for you, whining for your absence, and jealous of every woman you speak to? Upon my honour, I don't know any thing half so troublesome—hah, Lady Rentless?

SP.SPEAKER: LADY.
SP.P: Dreadful, my Lord! but Charles is so romantic: now do but observe how we live together. Is my Lord ever vexatiously uneasy on my account? Or am I ridiculously anxious on his? Yet, we are always chearful when met, and happy when separate: are not we, my Lord?

SP.SPEAKER: LORD.
SP.P: To be sure, perfectly so.

SP.SPEAKER: LADY.
SP.P: Indeed, Charles, you must got quit of these vulgar no∣tions; you are as bad as Lady Pure: I'll tell you, my Lord; you know the Dowager, she is always dream∣ing about propriety; well, she teaz'd me to death the other night at the Festino, for a list of my next week's engage∣ments, wanting me to sit an evening with her, as she calls it.—Ma'am, says I, on Sunday I must be at Lady Brag's, Monday at the Pantheon, Tuesday and Wednes∣day, several private parties, Thursday we see masks, Fri∣day I go forty miles to play Venus in Lady Scribble∣dum's petite piece, on Saturday I return to the opera, and—But an't this a little inconsistant, cried she, with his Lord∣ship's unhappy situation? Unhappy situation, Lady Pure! you rave! my Lord is the gayest man in town; always alive; always in company; keeps the best table; runs the best matches; listened to in the House; ador'd by the wo∣men; respected by the men; full of wit; full of gallantry, 'twould do your Ladyship good to have a tête à téte with him; upon which up she started, and I never set eyes on her afterwards.

SP.SPEAKER: LORD.
SP.P: Excellent! upon my honour; if you was not Lady Rentless, I do believe I should be your inamorato.

SP.SPEAKER: LADY.
SP.P: Your Lordship, too, is not without your pretensions; but foolery in marriage is a shocking idea after all.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLES.
SP.P: There I agree with you intirely.

DIV2.P: Mi Lor, here be de merchand vid de bill for—

SP.SPEAKER: LORD.
SP.P: De bill—send the rascal away, I'm not to be spoke with, I'm going this instant to the levee.

SP.SPEAKER: COQUIN,
SP.P: Mi Lor, I give your billet to Mademoiselle Uniform, and she—[Talking aside.]

SP.SPEAKER: LORD,
SP.P: Well, let me examine that account.

DIV2.STAGE: Enter a SERVANT, who delivers a Note to Lady RENT.

SP.SPEAKER: LADY.
SP.P: Ah! this is Labradore's hand, a billet-doux, after the manner of the Jews; let us see—[Runs over the Letter.] “Will certainly be at your Ladyship's breakfast to-mor∣row afternoon.—Will there fix an appointment and restore the diamonds, but must put them on myself; your Labradore's own little hands.” Very well, very well, it requires no answer. A delightful figure he will out amongst my company! but I must humour the fel∣low, for between his roguery and my Lord's folly, I have been absolutely defrauded of my diamonds; but if I can fairly recover my own trinkets, and at the same time justly mortify my Lord's pride by a little innocent trea∣chery with this Jew, I am sure no woman of feeling or enterprize will blame me. Well, my Lord, I suppose we shall meet at dinner, to welcome Sir Andrew and his daughter. Good bye, Charles, I need not doubt your be∣ing at home. Adieu, adieu; your servant, my Lord. [Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: LORD.
SP.P: Your servant, my Lady. Well, Charles, how do you dispose of yourself this morning? I'll e'en take a peep in∣to the house; when one has nothing else to do, it's rather a good lounge. Can I set you down any where?

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLES.
SP.P: My Lord, I'll attend you with all my heart; and, in∣deed, I think no member ought to be absent from his duty at this time.

SP.SPEAKER: LORD.
SP.P: True, Charles; and faith let them say what they will, I am a very useful member at present; for, upon my soul, I don't think any man can speak feelingly on the ruin of his country, that is not a little whimsically situated him∣self. [Exeunt.

DIV2.HEAD: SCENE IV.
DIV2.STAGE: SERVANTS shewing in Sir ANDREW and Miss ACORN, in travelling Dresses.

SP.SPEAKER: SERVANT.
SP.P: Sir, my Lord is just gone out; but I'll tell the maid, to tell the housekeeper, to tell my Lady's woman, to tell her Ladyship, that you are here. [Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR ANDREW.
SP.P: Zounds! this is like an introduction to the Grand Sig∣nior! Well, child, I hope you are not fatigued with your journey, tho' a pretty good distance this from Acorn-hall, and might tire a stronger constitution than yours?

SP.SPEAKER: HARRIOT.
SP.P: Indeed, Sir, I am not in the least fatigued, the novelty of every thing around me would prevent that.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR ANDREW.
SP.P:
Why true, child, every thing is new to you, and to me too, I think; I intended to have got here just before dinner, and breakfast is scarce over on our arrival. My
Lady Rentless, too, beginning to dress! Ah, I don't like this affectation of making good breeding inconsistent with good hours.

SP.SPEAKER: HARRIOT.
SP.P: These, I suppose, Sir, are trifling differences, that certain ranks will always indulge in.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR ANDREW.
SP.P: I don't know that; but when certain ranks pride them∣selves only upon such distinctions, it shews me they have no better to boast of; but come, child, I won't be cen∣sorious; Lord and Lady Rentless are young, his father was a very intimate friend of mine, and on that account, as well as on yours, I have been induced to make this visit; but I hope Charles has not been corrupted by bad example.

SP.SPEAKER: HARRIOT.
SP.P: Indeed, Sir, I think it is impossible; and you, when you last saw him, was of the same opinion.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR ANDREW.
SP.P: True, but times alter, and young men change. How∣ever, I am no croaker: but such a guardian as Lord Rentless, and such a school of education as London.—

SP.SPEAKER: HARRIOT.
SP.P: You said, Sir, you would not be censorious.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR ANDREW.
SP.P: I tell you I am not censorious; have-n't I lived all my life in the country, and do you suppose I don't know the world? Mark me, I don't mean the world as it is, but the world as it should be. I hope, now, when you are married to Charles, notwithstanding your fortune will be large—I mean after my death—for don't imagine I will leave myself a beggar.

SP.SPEAKER: HARRIOT.
SP.P: Believe me, my dear Sir, I have no such wish.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR ANDREW.
SP.P:
It may be so, but I hope that when you do marry, I say, that you will not think of keeping such a parade of
useless domesticks, as I see in this house, employed only in waiting upon each other.

SP.SPEAKER: HARRIOT.
SP.P: That, Sir, must be left to my husband.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR ANDREW.
SP.P: True, child, so it should; I hate to see wives directing too much: that was the only fault your mother had, and indeed she indulged it; but then I was of an easy disposition, and never contradicted any body.

SP.SPEAKER: HARRIOT.
SP.P: Allow me to say, Sir, that my mother—

SP.SPEAKER: SIR ANDREW.
SP.P: Hold, I must contradict you there.

SP.SPEAKER: HARRIOT.
SP.P: Dear Sir, if you will but recollect—

SP.SPEAKER: SIR ANDREW.
SP.P: Don't I tell you, I hate contradiction; remember, I tell you, a complying disposition is the foundation of matrimonial happiness.

SP.SPEAKER: HARRIOT.
SP.P: I hope, my dear papa, that you have not seen in me—

SP.SPEAKER: SIR ANDREW.
SP.P: I don't say I have, but marriage makes great alteration; I was sometimes apt to be a little fretted myself; but then your mother and I lived entirely in the country, and had a great deal of time upon our hands.

SP.SPEAKER: HARRIOT.
SP.P: Indeed, I must do you the justice to agree—

SP.SPEAKER: SIR ANDREW.
SP.P: I can't say that; we had our quarrels too, but then they made matrimony the sweeter, otherwise we should scarce have known the value of regard; and if it were not for interruption—

SP.SPEAKER: HARRIOT.
SP.P: But sure, Sir,—

SP.SPEAKER: SIR ANDREW.
SP.P: I hate interruption, child, and therefore I was going to tell you—

DIV2.P: Zounds, somebody will interrupt one at last.

SP.SPEAKER: SERVANT.
SP.P: Madam, her Ladyship presents her compliments to you, and will be glad to have the honour of seeing you in her dressing-room.

SP.SPEAKER: HARRIOT.
SP.P: I'll attend her. I suppose, papa, we shall meet pre∣sently. [Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: SERVANT.
SP.P: Your honour would probably choose to walk into his Lordship's library.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR ANDREW.
SP.P: [Mimicking his tone.] His Lordship's library. So I will—No, I won't, now I think better of it; for what can his library produce to entertain me? I want no ra∣cing calendar, or calculation of the odds, or approved cosmeticks, psha!—But I may as well go;—the conver∣sation of the dead can't be worse than that of the living; I defy it. [Exit.

DIV2.HEAD: SCENE V.
DIV2.STAGE: GOLD WAITER to BROOKES'S. [Lolling on a Table.]
DIV2.P: A pretty place I am got into here; who the devil ever thought of seeing a fashionable waiter, like me, stuck in∣to a library! Heigh ho! I wish my Lord would come home, I can't lose all my time in waiting to settle with him for a few paltry rouleaus. Let me see what engagements I have upon my hands—Lord Barebone to Sir John Scrape, 50 rouleaus; House to Kit Cricket, Esq; 500. Aye, zounds what a life we gold waiters to the clubs lead, always on the wing, night and day; I must make my fortune son, for I shall never hold out above two winters longer.—But what queer old put have we here?
Ah! here's some young sprig of quality, I suppose. [Aside.] Sir, I am your most obedient humble servant.

SP.SPEAKER: WAITER.
SP.P: Damn me, he appears nobody, I'll be genteel. [Aside.] Sir, I am yours. [Affectedly.]

SP.SPEAKER: SIR ANDREW.
SP.P: I hope I have not interrupted you; I presume you are waiting for my Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: WAITER.
SP.P: Yes, I am, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR ANDREW.
SP.P: He's well engaged, they tell me, as every member ought, in the public cause. But pray, Sir, have you heard what passed in the house yesterday?

SP.SPEAKER: WAITER.
SP.P: O damme, nothing, we had nothing done at our house yesterday. Nothing damme.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR ANDREW.
SP.P: Our house! a member of parliament, a respectable character; it's a pity he swears so much. [Aside.] So, there was nothing done you say, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: WAITER.
SP.P: O no, mere chicken play; scarce a rouleau passed the whole evening; damn'd poor and very cautious, not a dove amongst them.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR ANDREW.
SP.P: Sir, a dove! What the devil is all this? [Aside.]

SP.SPEAKER: WAITER.
SP.P: O yes, now I think of it, we elected Governor Divi∣dend; the first of pigeons, in full plumage, just arrived from Madrass.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR ANDREW.
SP.P: Elected! Oh, now I comprehend him. Pray Sir, for what place? I do not remember his name.

SP.SPEAKER: WAITER.
SP.P: Place! why into the vacancy, damme; we shall all have a pluck at him before the campaign's at an end.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR ANDREW.
SP.P: Campaign! What in America, you mean?

SP.SPEAKER: WAITER.
SP.P: America! Damme, he seems a fool. I'll queer him. [Aside.] Why, you'd make an excellent dove, old gentleman, with a few rouleaus in your pocket, and the bones in your hand.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR ANDREW.
SP.P: Really, Sir, I don't know what you mean.

SP.SPEAKER: WAITER.
SP.P: Who said you did? [Aside.] Why there was just such another gentleman as you we elected the other day—Gad, the first hand he took won every thing; then doubled stakes; threw out every time, and in two hours was as bare as a starv'd blood hound—not a shilling left, but was swept out of the house next morning in the carpet.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR ANDREW.
SP.P: Upon my word, Sir, this may be all very fashio∣nable and parliamentary, and a language that you may be accustom'd to, but I must say that I don't under∣stand it.

SP.SPEAKER: WAITER.
SP.P: No! why nobody understands any thing else now a-days.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR ANDREW.
SP.P: As that is the case, Sir, we may as well drop the conversation and have recourse to books.

SP.SPEAKER: WAITER.
SP.P: Books! I'm glad you mention'd them—Here they are! [Taking out a pack of cards.] I never go with∣out them. Come, sit down, old gentleman; come, [Clapping him on the back.] you shall have your choice—vingt un, piquet, quinze—

SP.SPEAKER: SIR ANDREW.
SP.P: [In a passion.] Why, you ignorant wretch!—

SP.SPEAKER: WAITER.
SP.P: Ignorant! Damme, I'll soon shew you the contrary—Here, I have got Hoyle in my pocket—[Gives him a book.]—Now ask me what you like, and see if I don't answer you.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR ANDREW.
SP.P: Why, puppy! hangdog! [Throwing the book at him.] what do you take me for?—a compiler of games and calculator of chances! Zounds! I'll let you know—

SP.SPEAKER: LORD.
SP.P: Hah! my dear Sir Andrew—I rejoice to see you—But what is the meaning of all this?

SP.SPEAKER: SIR ANDREW.
SP.P: [Flurried.] Ho! ho!—Upon my word, my Lord, I can scarce tell—but the gentleman there can probably inform you.

SP.SPEAKER: WAITER.
SP.P: No, indeed, my Lord, not I, upon my honour.

SP.SPEAKER: LORD.
SP.P: Pray, Sir Andrew, be so kind as to let me into the secret—I hope no incivility.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR ANDREW.
SP.P: I'll tell you what, my Lord—I have heard indeed that in this general corruption, our representatives were changed from what they used to be—but an unlooked-for insult from a member of parliament—a pillar of the constitution make such an offer—

SP.SPEAKER: LORD.
SP.P: Upon my word, Sir Andrew, I don't understand you—but if you refer to him—Nickit is in general reckon'd as civil a waiter as—

SP.SPEAKER: SIR ANDREW.
SP.P: A what! a waiter? Get out of my sight immedi∣ately, or by—

SP.SPEAKER: WAITER.
SP.P: [Running out.] O yes, with all my heart—and I hope never to come into it again. [Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR ANDREW.
SP.P: Zounds! this adds to the insult—A waiter! Very well, Sir Andrew Acorn! I'll tell you what, my Lord—I'll tell you what—but 'tis no matter—the times are so alter'd—so I say nothing.

SP.SPEAKER: LORD.
SP.P: Pon honour, Sir Andrew, I do not yet comprehend the mistake you have made. To be sure the people of our club are obliged to keep up a certain appearance, and a certain polish in their manners, but we seldom hear of their passing for members of parliament.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR ANDREW.
SP.P: Oh, my Lord, I am quite satisfied—but I am deter∣mined [Enter a Servant, who wispers Lord Rentless.] to make no more mistakes, for I'll neither believe my ears nor my understanding—that at least I'll take care of. [Walks about the room.

SP.SPEAKER: LORD.
SP.P: [To Servant.] Metaphor, the auctioneer! Zounds! Say I'm not at home—Don't let him come up. [Exit Servant.] Gad, I must stop him. [Going out.] The devil!

SP.SPEAKER: METAPHOR.
SP.P: My Lud! your Ludship's most obedient. [To Sir Andrew.] Sir, I am your most obsequious, profound—

SP.SPEAKER: SIR ANDREW.
SP.P: Now, what the devil can this fellow be? [Aside.

SP.SPEAKER: METAPHOR.
SP.P: Took the liberty of popping in upon your Ludship in the way to our rooms.

SP.SPEAKER: LORD.
SP.P: True, my dear Metaphor—I plainly see—

SP.SPEAKER: SIR ANDREW.
SP.P: Upon my soul now I don't. Pray, my Lord, let the gentleman explain himself.

SP.SPEAKER: METAPHOR.
SP.P: By all means, my Lord. Cannot but arrogate feli∣city to myself in attracting the notice of so accom∣plish'd—

SP.SPEAKER: SIR ANDREW.
SP.P: What! heh! does he mean me?

SP.SPEAKER: LORD.
SP.P: To be sure! don't you understand him?

SP.SPEAKER: SIR ANDREW.
SP.P: Why really, I must confess, the gentleman's remarks are rather—

SP.SPEAKER: METAPHOR.
SP.P: True; I anticipate your words. You would say, my remarks are happy, and elucidation splendid. Crave your Ludship's indulgence to a little specimen of the beauties of description to accelerate the sale of a cer∣tain estate.

SP.SPEAKER: LORD.
SP.P: Not for the world—I won't trouble you at this time▪

SP.SPEAKER: METAPHOR.
SP.P: Sorry to disobey; but cannot but flatter myself it will be found enrich'd with some poetical decorations.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR ANDREW.
SP.P: Poetical decorations! Pray, my Lord, let us see them; I am a great friend to genius.

SP.SPEAKER: LORD
SP.P: Indeed, Sir Andrew, you'll never understand—

SP.SPEAKER: SIR ANDREW.
SP.P: Yes, yes, I understand him now. I see he is a poet. [To Metaphor.] Yes, Sir, I see plainly that you are a favourite of the muses, a dealer in poetry.

SP.SPEAKER: METAPHOR.
SP.P: True, Sir—had the honour of knocking down Bell's edition yesterday for little more than the valua∣tion of the binding.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR ANDREW.
SP.P: What, Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: METAPHOR.
SP.P: I perceive, Sir, you are astonished; but could not draw one penny more, tho' the audience was remarka∣bly brilliant, and myself not unfortunate in the display of what we call pulpit wit.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR ANDREW.
SP.P: [Aside.] Aye, I suppose that is some new poetical flight, tho' I never heard of that figure before.

SP.SPEAKER: METAPHOR.
SP.P:
But to the point—Give me leave, my Lud—“To the judicious—A villa, nominated—blank—in a complete rural retirement, happily environ'd by pu∣blic roads, duly distant, and discreetly plann'd—blank miles from the capital—embosom'd by nature in loftly trees, and water'd by luxurious streams from
art—vicinage desirable—site unequall'd—accom∣modation perfect—and brilliancy insufferable.”

SP.SPEAKER: SIR ANDREW.
SP.P: Hey day! why, what is all this prose run mad?

SP.SPEAKER: METAPHOR.
SP.P: Yes, I flatter myself, as prettily penn'd—

SP.SPEAKER: SIR ANDREW.
SP.P: Why, it may be prettily penn'd; but, I must confess, I am not sensible of all its beauties.

SP.SPEAKER: METAPHOR.
SP.P: No—then you shall see the plan.

SP.SPEAKER: LORD.
SP.P: By no means. Zounds! Sir Andrew will find out that my estates are on sale. [Aside.] Won't trouble you now, Mr. Metaphor.

SP.SPEAKER: METAPHOR.
SP.P: No trouble in the universe—have them in my pocket.

SP.SPEAKER: LORD.
SP.P: [Bowing him out.] Can't think of it, Mr. Metaphor. Good morning to you.

SP.SPEAKER: METAPHOR.
SP.P: I beg no ceremony—

SP.SPEAKER: LORD.
SP.P: Your most obedient.

SP.SPEAKER: METAPHOR.
SP.P: If your Lordship has the least necessity—

SP.SPEAKER: LORD.
SP.P: Sir, your very humble Servant.

SP.SPEAKER: METAPHOR.
SP.P: I can easily advance—

SP.SPEAKER: LORD.
SP.P: Pray, Sir, retire—

SP.SPEAKER: METAPHOR.
SP.P: Five hundred pounds on your Lordship's own note.

SP.SPEAKER: LORD.
SP.P: Sir, I beg you won't trouble yourself. Good morn∣ing to you. [Bowing him out.] You must not mind, he's mad. [To Sir Andrew as he goes out.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR ANDREW.
SP.P: Mad! so we are all, I believe. Zounds! I neither see, hear, or understand. I took him for a poet, till he offered to advance more money in a minute than the whole fraternity could raise in a twelvemonth. [Exit.

DIV2.HEAD: ACT III. SCENE I.
DIV2.STAGE: CHARLES leading HARRIOT forward from a Harpsichord.

SP.SPEAKER: HARRIOT.
SP.P: FY, Charles, why can't you let me finish?

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLES.
SP.P: Enough of music, my dear Harriot—though you came here yesterday, I have scarce had time to repeat to you how inexpressively happy I am.

SP.SPEAKER: HARRIOT.
SP.P: Why, what signifies repeating it. I know all you are going to say about happiness, and—

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLES.
SP.P: Indeed, but you do not; for I was going to assure you, that the stile of living, and the manners of Lord and Lady Rentless, which I see you disapprove, are as unpleasing to me as—

SP.SPEAKER: HARRIOT.
SP.P: Ah, Charles, indeed I should be unhappy if—

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLES.
SP.P: Believe me, I foresaw your apprehensions. But rest assured, my dearest Harriot, that tho' Lord Rentless is my guardian, and it seem'd my father's will that I should live immediately under his Lordship's eye, yet I entirely dislike his mode of life.

SP.SPEAKER: HARRIOT.
SP.P: Yes, yes, entirely, no doubt of it. Who would have imagined, when you came in a discreet manner to solicit the honour of my fair hand after our meeting at Scar∣bro', that the sentimental Charles Woodbine was the ward of one of the most fashionable libertines about town. Ought you not to be asham'd of cheating the heart of a poor simple girl into approbation? Mind, I only say approbation; nothing more.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLES.
SP.P: Indeed, Harriot, I cannot allow you to trifle, un∣less you will assure me, you are convinc'd I mean to pursue that plan when we are united—

SP.SPEAKER: HARRIOT.
SP.P: O fye! And can you think that I, who propose to pass my life in a quiet, good, domestic way in the country, watching my flowering shrubs, nursing my birds, and, and—in short, do you imagine I will give my hand to a man who is wedded to this dissipated town? Oh, no.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLES.
SP.P: But I tell you I am not wedded—

SP.SPEAKER: HARRIOT.
SP.P: Who sits up whole nights at routs and assemblies, and rises in the morning to preside over fêtes champêtres.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLES.
SP.P: But, my dear Harriot, I do no such thing; I hate—

SP.SPEAKER: HARRIOT.
SP.P: Who loves hazard with my Lord, and flirtation with my Lady; who has forgot all the charms of the coun∣try, except what he sees from a fantastic garden in town: so I think I may as well return home by my∣self.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLES.
SP.P: Come, come, Harriot, I will not be vex'd at all the indifference you affect. I know you will pay a strict regard to your promises.

SP.SPEAKER: HARRIOT.
SP.P: Promises! Pray now what might I promise?

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLES.
SP.P: Need I mention it? Can my dear Harriot have for∣gotten the morning I left the country, with what a charming reluctance she promis'd—

SP.SPEAKER: HARRIOT.
SP.P: I won't hear a word you say.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLES.
SP.P: That on our return she would bestow her hand where she had already given her heart.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR ANDREW.
SP.P: [Coming forward.] To be sure she did—and pray who denies it?

SP.SPEAKER: HARRIET.
SP.P: [Confused.] Indeed, my dear Sir—

SP.SPEAKER: SIR ANDREW.
SP.P: Yes, child, I know you confess it. But, Charles, you should not require a female to repeat a promise drawn from her by an acquiescence with my wishes. Once said, you know, is sufficient.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLES.
SP.P: Upon my honour, Sir Andrew, you mistake th matter.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR ANDREW.
SP.P: You mistake the matter, you mean. No, no, few people see clearer than I do.

SP.SPEAKER: HARRIOT.
SP.P: But on this occasion, my dear papa, I must say—

SP.SPEAKER: SIR ANDREW.
SP.P: Yes, I know I am right. Ah, Harriot, you are just like poor Lady Acorn, always happy to agree with me. Well, she was a good woman, and, I must own, seldom contradicted me. But come, children, all the world in this house are on foot.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLES.
SP.P: What, busy for the fête?

SP.SPEAKER: HARRIOT.
SP.P: Yes, for a rural breakfast in London in the middle of the day.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR ANDREW.
SP.P:
Ay, there's such preparation of tea, and music, and ices, and dancing, and chocolate, and tents, and I
know not what, that one can scarce turn one's self about. But, come, let's in, or rather let's out to this fête, and see if a London garden, with a few shrubs from a hot house, can rival the ancient bowling-green and stately oaks of Acorn Hall.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLES.
SP.P: Sir, we'll attend you.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR ANDREW.
SP.P: [Taking them under each arm.] Come along, I say, come along with me. You know each other's minds, and therefore what signifies repeating it so often.

DIV2.HEAD: SCENE II.

SP.SPEAKER: LADY.
SP.P: [Looking at herself in the glass.] This is not my day, positively. I don't know how, but that aukward girl from the country, with her healthy looks and hoyden manners, has put me out of spirits, as well as out of countenance. Heigh ho! And this morning dress is not quite so well as I expected. Champignon has some taste, but then she cannot fit an English shape do what she will. Oh, my Lord, are you there?

DIV2.STAGE: Enter Lord RENTLESS, with a paper in his hand.

SP.SPEAKER: LORD.
SP.P:
Yes. I have just been looking over your list to see whom we are to have—Lord Canter! What's he upon his legs still?—The Duchess of Poney, Sir
Anthony Heelpiece, Sir Sampson Strut—aye, aye—I don't believe I know above half of them.

SP.SPEAKER: LADY.
SP.P: Nor I; but on these occasions one only fills up va∣cancies; and provided they are but tolerable figures and people of fashion—

SP.SPEAKER: LORD.
SP.P: Very well, very well, as you say. [Reads.] "Baron Squat, Bishop Butter, Mr. Labradore"—Hah, why, we seem to have all religions together. But how comes Labradore amongst them? Is he quite in style enough? He's but a very tolerable figure indeed!

SP.SPEAKER: LADY.
SP.P: One must be civil to the creature, you know, my Lord, on your account.

SP.SPEAKER: LORD.
SP.P: True; and as he pays for the entertainment, in fact, he has some right to see how his money is dis∣posed of. But where's your brother, General Probe? I don't see his name amongst them. I suppose he is not returned from review hunting.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR ANDREW.
SP.P: I hope I don't interrupt you?

SP.SPEAKER: LADY.
SP.P: Oh, no, Sir Andrew; there's nobody here but my Lord, so you don't interrupt us in the least. I beg you'll come in.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR ANDREW.
SP.P:
Well, my Lady, I see you are ready for the fête I think you call it. I have been looking into the gar∣den,
and, upon my word, I should almost take it for a country wake.

SP.SPEAKER: LORD.
SP.P: You see, Sir Andrew, what we can do when we have a mind: there's no occasion to go two hundred miles from London for rural beauties.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR ANDREW.
SP.P: Nor any other, my Lord; for I met three shep∣herdesses this moment properly accoutred for the scene, with such a store of health upon their cheeks, as would outvie a whole group of milk-maids; tho' I fear it is not quite so durable; for one of them wanted to treat me with a whisper, and I don't know whether I have not brought some part of the bloom away with me.

SP.SPEAKER: LORD.
SP.P: Oh, fye, Sir Andrew! you should have spared their blushes.

SP.SPEAKER: LADY.
SP.P: Come! no reflection upon my shepherdesses; they won't bear that, I assure you.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR ANDREW.
SP.P: I beg pardon, my Lady; I only wish they were not quite so easily put out of countenance.

SP.SPEAKER: SERVANT.
SP.P: Doctor Quintessence—Would your Ladyship be pleased to admit him?

SP.SPEAKER: LADY.
SP.P: Certainly. [Exit Servant.] Sir Andrew! I must introduce you to the Doctor: he is the first elegant of the faculty; the medicin à-la-mode.

SP.SPEAKER: LORD.
SP.P: Yes, Sir Andrew—none of your antique figures; your veterans of the vieille cour, whose science was en∣rolled in the gorgon curls of their periwigs; no, no, this gentleman—but here he is.
[Doctor Quintessence without.] Let the chairmen take care of Pompey, and place him on the seat.

SP.SPEAKER: DOCTOR.
SP.P: My good Lord, came early on purpose to look on you, and give you my passavant for the day. But how does your Ladyship? Favour me with your fin∣ger—Ah! bon, bon—Your Ladyship's pulse is in delicious order.

SP.SPEAKER: LADY.
SP.P: Yes, Doctor, I find myself greatly recovered from my yesterday's ennui. That nabob's wife, with her tawdry hangings, and gilt girandoles, quite overcame me.

SP.SPEAKER: DOCTOR.
SP.P: The effect upon the animal spirits must indeed have been shocking. But your Ladyship seems somewhat abattû to-day. I fear you have not left off vanilla in your chocolate, and put amber in its place. Do you confine yourself to claret of the vintage seventy-five, carefully put up in champaigne bottles?

SP.SPEAKER: SIR ANDREW.
SP.P: Carefully put up in champaigne bottles! Pray, Sir, do you look on that of so much consequence?

SP.SPEAKER: DOCTOR.
SP.P:
Inexpressible—the smallest circumstance may dis∣order the whole nervous system. The thickness of a
phial, or the position of a cork, may destroy a pa∣tient inevitably.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR ANDREW.
SP.P: May I be so bold as to ask, Sir, if you practise physic?

SP.SPEAKER: DOCTOR.
SP.P: Physic! throw physic to the dogs. I am an admi∣rer of the art, an amateur as one may say: but my practice is confined to the sensations. I raise, or I as∣swage nervous sensibility—not but that I sometimes use more desperate remedies—there are instances where I have been known to prescribe essence of peaches, or the more poignant juice of pines.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR ANDREW.
SP.P: Pines and peaches! One would swear he was a gardiner. I see, Sir, you have made botany your chief study.

SP.SPEAKER: DOCTOR.
SP.P: Botany! Oh, no—Electricity! tepid baths, soft airs, beautiful objects, Lady Rentless! The exercise of hazard, my Lord, for the arms and lungs, and that of dancing for the legs and body, with now and then a gentle trill upon the lute—This is my art—these are my prescriptions.

SP.SPEAKER: LADY.
SP.P: Charming physician! Are you not in raptures, Sir Andrew?

SP.SPEAKER: SIR ANDREW.
SP.P: Upon my word, my Lady, I must say the materia medica is much alter'd of late.

SP.SPEAKER: DOCTOR.
SP.P: True; such a method might not altogether suit your habit, for you are in a most dangerous state, Sir Andrew, I assure you.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR ANDREW.
SP.P:
Dangerous state! Me, Sir! Why I never was
ill in my life, but once with the small pox, and ano∣ther time when I was found amongst the dead in the service of my country at an election feast.

SP.SPEAKER: DOCTOR.
SP.P: So much the worse, Sir; so much the worse—You are indeed in a forc'd state of robustness, which some people denominate health; but here is my Lord, who, tho' as pale as a sheet, and has even paralytic tenden∣cies [Lord Rentless starts.] may outlive you. I would almost ensure his life for three months to come.

SP.SPEAKER: LORD.
SP.P: Upon my word, you and I, Sir Andrew, seem to be in a very hopeful situation.

SP.SPEAKER: LADY.
SP.P: Yes, you see how dangerous it is to live in the country and fancy yourself well.

SP.SPEAKER: LORD.
SP.P: In a forced state of robustness, Sir Andrew.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR ANDREW.
SP.P: To be sure it's better to enjoy all the advantages of London, as pale as a sheet, with paralytic tendencies, my Lord—No, no, let physicians say what they please, I will fancy—no, I won't fancy—for I am certain I never was better in my life.

SP.SPEAKER: DOCTOR.
SP.P: Forgive me, Sir Andrew; there seems a small irri∣tation upon your nerves, which inclines you to be a little positive or so, but I—

SP.SPEAKER: SIR ANDREW.
SP.P: But I say, it is no such thing—

SP.SPEAKER: DOCTOR.
SP.P:
I see it—however, will take the liberty of just touching your pulse—have got a small instrument on
purpose to ascertain the disposition to a scruple—In∣dulge me with the favour of your wrist, Sir Andrew.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR ANDREW.
SP.P: Indeed, Sir, I will not; I don't want to be play'd the fool with at my time of life.

SP.SPEAKER: LADY.
SP.P: Pray, Sir Andrew, indulge the doctor; he never does any body any harm.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR ANDREW.
SP.P: No, nor any good neither, I believe.

SP.SPEAKER: DOCTOR.
SP.P: Hah! A very violent irritation indeed! Wou'd wish you to take four spoonfuls of rasberry ice to regulate the internal heat.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR ANDREW.
SP.P: Zounds! I never had any heat in my life, but after a fox-chace.

SP.SPEAKER: LORD.
SP.P: Come, Doctor, I see Sir Andrew has no wish to try the experiment; so let us adjourn the consultation and go to the company.

SP.SPEAKER: DOCTOR.
SP.P: With inexpressible pleasure. The honour of your La∣dyship's finger. But, Sir Andrew, you'll certainly die, mind my word. [Looking back at Sir Andrew.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR ANDREW.
SP.P: No, no, Doctor—but I beg pardon—I contradict no∣body. [Exeunt.

DIV2.HEAD: SCENE III.

SP.SPEAKER: COQUIN.
SP.P: Dis dejeuné, dis breakfast, be von pret divertissement en verité, and, bygar, I will amuse myself en attendant. Here, Jeames, Jeames!

SP.SPEAKER: SERVANT.
SP.P: Well, Master Coquin, what do you want with me?

SP.SPEAKER: COQUIN.
SP.P: Stepa you up stair, and fetch me de habit galone, de fine coat, dat belong to my Lor. Make a haste.

SP.SPEAKER: SERVANT.
SP.P: I'll wait upon you immediately; but there's Labradore, the great Jew, just getting out of his chair. I must shew him into the company. [Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: COQUIN.
SP.P: Bon, bon, Monsieur Labradore, you come here to my Lady, and I will go and return you the compliment. By gar you should teach your daughter to write von fair hand, for I have great difficulté to understand her billet doux. [Taking out a Note.] But no matter for dat, she be bien amoureuse de moi dis Mademoiselle Judith, and I am forte attaché to her fortune.

DIV2.P: There, Master Coquin, there's the cloaths. You don't want to put them on and go into the company, do you?

SP.SPEAKER: COQUIN.
SP.P: Fi donc! fi donc! you need not stay. [Exit Servant.] Ah, voila l'habit superb! en verité: I shall look bien charmant. Ma chere Judith fancy me one nobleman, and by gar when we are dress de same, dere vill be no grand difference. [Exit.

DIV2.HEAD: SENE IV.
DIV2.STAGE: Discovers a great Company sitting at Breakfast. A Tent open at the End of the Stage. Four Tables, two at each Side. Lady Rentless, with Doctor Quintessence and Labradore, Alderman Uniform, Miss, and Lord Rentless, Harriot, Sir Andrew, Charles, &c. &c. Servants waiting.

SP.SPEAKER: ALDERMAN,
SP.P: Stop my pay, my Lord, but it makes a martial appear∣ance.

SP.SPEAKER: LORD.
SP.P: Well, Captain, are you resolved for the camp?

SP.SPEAKER: ALDERMAN.
SP.P: Fixt as a bayonet, or may I never pass muster again.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss UNIFORM.
SP.P: Indeed, my Lord, my Papa and I are quite ready.

SP.SPEAKER: LORD.
SP.P: That's right, my charming Miss, you shall not want encouragement.

SP.SPEAKER: LADY,
SP.P: Your Lordship will have a very elegant volunteer in Miss Uniform.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss UNIFORM,
SP.P: I shall be proud to be instructed by his Lordship.

DIV2.P: Pray, Sir Andrew, have you heard the news? They say, Miss Evergreen, is gone off with a Jew.

SP.SPEAKER: LABRADORE.
SP.P: Bring me a dish of shocolate.

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. QUINT.
SP.P: Oh, very common in practice; I was call'd in, the other day, to the Dutchess of Dismal's youngest daughter, who rav'd of nothing but the graces of Harlequin Friday.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir ANDREW.
SP.P: That could be no fault of yours Doctor, as you always prescribe beautiful objects, you know.

SP.SPEAKER: ALDERMAN.
SP.P: Beautiful! Disband me, if I have not enlisted a brace of black drummers this morning, as fine fellows, and stood as fair to the eye as you wou'd wish to see.

DIV2.P: I suppose, my Lord, you will be call'd out early to the field?

SP.SPEAKER: ALDERMAN.
SP.P: Yes, I dare say we shall have warm work soon.

SP.SPEAKER: LABRADORE.
SP.P: Get me some ish!

SP.SPEAKER: Lord RENTLESS.
SP.P: But, Miss Uniform, you have not examin'd the gardens, The best view is here. [Leading her to the Front.] At Eight o'clock this evening—[Whispers.]

SP.SPEAKER: Miss UNIFORM.
SP.P: But is it proper and genteel, my Lord?

SP.SPEAKER: LORD.
SP.P: Nothing can be more the ton.

SP.SPEAKER: ALDERMAN,
SP.P: Pray, my Lord, may my daughter and I pitch our tent near yours.

SP.SPEAKER: LORD.
SP.P: Close, Mr Alderman. [Labradore and my Lady come forward.] My dear Miss. [Whispering.] won't you give me your—Soft, we shall be overheard.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss UNIFORM.
SP.P: Any thing, my Lord, rather than that. [Retires.

SP.SPEAKER: LADY,
SP.P: Nay, Mr. Labradore, you promis'd I should have my bracelets again to-day.

SP.SPEAKER: LABRADORE.
SP.P: Upon my salvation, I shall bring them this evening to the Hotel.

SP.SPEAKER: LADY.
SP.P: At what hour did you say?

SP.SPEAKER: LABRADORE.
SP.P: About eight o'clock; let me entreat you not to fail, my dear Ladyship.

SP.SPEAKER: LADY.
SP.P: Hush! we are observed. [Retires.

SP.SPEAKER: ALDERMAN,
SP.P: Tie me to the halberds, if this is not all very innocent and pretty. Is n't it, my Lord?

SP.SPEAKER: LABRADORE
SP.P: Well, Maishter Alderman, you see I wash got into the line.

SP.SPEAKER: ALDERMAN.
SP.P: Then take care how you get out of it, or you may pay for promotion.

SP.SPEAKER: LABRADORE.
SP.P: Yesh, but we know how to pay people in their own coin.

DIV2.STAGE: Lady RENTLESS, CHARLES, and HARRIOT, advance.

SP.SPEAKER: LADY.
SP.P: Well, Harriot! But I need not ask you how you are entertained, so I won't break in upon your tête à tête. My dear Sir Andrew, you don't give me your opinion of our breakfast.

SP.SPEAKER: LORD.
SP.P: Nor, Sir Andrew, you don't tell me how you like my new uniform. What say you to the Alderman's jacket?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir ANDREW.
SP.P: The Alderman! Oh, there, I ask pardon, very suitable, indeed.—I never saw any thing so absurd in my life. [Aside.

SP.SPEAKER: ALDERMAN.
SP.P: May I never reach the standard, but it's convenient and short.

SP.SPEAKER: LABRADORE
SP.P: Short indeed! Agh! my dear Ladysh, how disagree∣able it is to listen to some men.

SP.SPEAKER: LADY.
SP.P: You are perfectly in the right, Mr. Labradore. That my Lord's folly should expose me to such impertinencies!

SP.SPEAKER: DOCTOR.
SP.P: Your Ladyship knows how to distinguish grace, the very essence of politeness.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir ANDREW.
SP.P: And as efficacious as the juice of pines. [Flourish sym∣phony,] But zounds, get out of the way, here's something to harmonize us.

SP.SPEAKER: LADY.
SP.P: Yes; my shepherdesses; don't put 'em out of counte∣nance again, Sir Andrew.

DIV2.STAGE: Enter a Troop of Shepherds and Shepherdesses.

LG.L: Smiling Love, to thee belong,
Festive mirth, and rural song;
Come ye youthful, come ye gay,
Haste and join our roundelay.

SP.SPEAKER: SHEPHERDESS.
SP.L: Every sigh shall yield a smile.

SP.SPEAKER: SHEPHERD.
SP.L: Now no more afflict the swain,
Seldom fails to wound the heart.

DIV2.HEAD: ACT IV. SCENE I.
DIV2.STAGE: Labradore's House strangely furnished, tawdry and dirty; variety of Cloaths, and other Things; a Table, Wine, Bunch of Grapes, and Jews Cake.
Coquin and the Jew's Daughter sitting.

SP.SPEAKER: COQUIN,
SP.STAGE: disguised like a Lord with a star.
SP.P: EH, bien, ma chere—You no think your papa come home to dinner?

SP.SPEAKER: DAUGHTER.
SP.P: No, my dear Lord. He is gone out to breakfast with the peoples of fashion, and that will keep him till supper; so let me help you to some of this hweet grape.

SP.SPEAKER: COQUIN.
SP.P: [Tasting.] Ah! bon, bon—your grape be no sour, you sly littel fox, you. [Archly.]

SP.SPEAKER: DAUGHTER.
SP.P: But come, vid your glass of wine, eat a pice of our cakes. Eigh, what wou'd my father say, if he saw me give de Jewish cake to de dear littel Christian?

SP.SPEAKER: COQUIN.
SP.P: Ah! ah! But vat vil he say when he find de dear little Christian has run away vid his daughter, as well as his cake?

SP.SPEAKER: DAUGHTER.
SP.P: Aye; he does not know how true and disinterested our love is.

SP.SPEAKER: COQUIN.
SP.P: Disinterested! Certainement! à-propos, Have you secure de littel bijoux, de jewel, de bond, and de argent, just to amuse till I go vid you to my own country.

SP.SPEAKER: DAUGHTER.
SP.P:
Yesh; here they are all safe. Oh, how I long to be a French noblewomansh of quality! To see the
king and queen at supper, and sit up all night at cards.

SP.SPEAKER: COQUIN.
SP.P: Allons, my petite Israelite, by gar we got no time to lose. The parson is ready, and I have take d apartments express. [Going; a knocking at the door is heard.

SP.SPEAKER: DAUGHTER.
SP.P: Mosesh defend me! that is my father's knock.

SP.SPEAKER: SERVANT.
SP.P: Presherve us! here is my maishter come home. What shall we do! What shall we do!

SP.SPEAKER: COQUIN.
SP.P: Your master! Sacre Bleu!

SP.SPEAKER: DAUGHTER.
SP.P: Dear Rachel, where shall we put his Lordship?

SP.SPEAKER: SERVANT.
SP.P: Lorsh, Miss! I'm in such a twitteration—Suppose—suppose—we put him up the chimney.

SP.SPEAKER: COQUIN.
SP.P: Diable, n' emporte! Up de chimney! Parbleu, I shall be smoke. [Knocking harder without.

SP.SPEAKER: SERVANT.
SP.P: [Running out.] Well, then, you must manage it yourselves.

SP.SPEAKER: DAUGHTER.
SP.P: [Fetching the dress.] I have it. Here is one of our Rabbi's dresses which has luckily been left here. Sup∣pose you put it on. Quick, quick; it will deceive my father.

SP.SPEAKER: COQUIN.
SP.P: De tout mon coeur—Vid all my heart; any ting to deceive your father.

SP.SPEAKER: DAUGHTER.
SP.P: [Helping him to dress.] There, take this flapt hat.

SP.SPEAKER: COQUIN.
SP.P: What! all dat hat?

SP.SPEAKER: DAUGHTER.
SP.P: Yesh, yesh, my Lord. Your Lordship must affect to be sick, and your Lordship must try to speak in our dialect.

SP.SPEAKER: COQUIN.
SP.P: [Disguising himself.] My Lordship! my Lordship! By gar, my Lordship shall try to do any ting. Mon Dieu! I am Jewish Abbé.

SP.SPEAKER: LABRADORE.
SP.P: [Without as entering.] Why, Rachel. What was keep you so long from letting me in?

SP.SPEAKER: DAUGHTER.
SP.P: [Leaning over Coquin.] Well, good Sir, how do you find yourself? Better?

SP.SPEAKER: LABRADORE.
SP.P: Why, shild. What are you about? Ha! who have we here?

SP.SPEAKER: DAUGHTER.
SP.P: A father of our tribe who wash taken shick, and called in for a glash of water.

SP.SPEAKER: COQUIN.
SP.P: [Imitating a Jew.] Yesh, ver true. Hearing you was one of the goodsh short, Maishter Labradore, I josht took the liberty to make free with your house∣hold. I wash fall ill this morning at de sight of two of our brethren who wash execute only for copy one oder pershon's name.

SP.SPEAKER: LABRADORE.
SP.P: A very unlucky accident, indeed.

SP.SPEAKER: COQUIN.
SP.P: Oh, it wash very unguarded ting; and brings dis∣grace upon us all. Ooh! ooh! [Pretending to be sick.

SP.SPEAKER: LABRADORE.
SP.P: Sackcloth and ashes, so it doesh; but don't be cast down, father, there are a great many that escapeth yet. I begsh pardon though, I must step into the other room to fetch some diamonds I am going to disposh of. Mind the good father, child. [To his daughter as he goes out.

SP.SPEAKER: COQUIN.
SP.P: By gar, our plan succeeds en merveille, ma chere. Ah! [Kisses her.

SP.SPEAKER: LABRADORE.
SP.P: [Returning.] Father, won't you chuse any refresh∣ment?

SP.SPEAKER: COQUIN.
SP.P: Much oblige; but your daughter wash give me enough.

SP.SPEAKER: LABRADORE.
SP.P: [Going out again.] That's right; be comforted, and don't take it so much to heart.

SP.SPEAKER: COQUIN.
SP.P: [After he's gone—To the Jewess.] Mind what your good father says, child. [Mocking him.] Come, some more refresh. I will take it to heart, by gar, that I will.

SP.SPEAKER: DAUGHTER.
SP.P: Hush, hush, here he comes back again.

SP.SPEAKER: LABRADORE.
SP.P: Well, I hopesh you find yourself revived. I wash obliged to go out, but my daughter will take care of you.

SP.SPEAKER: COQUIN.
SP.P: Yesh, she wash ver kind—goodsh day to you, don't mind me—I shan't stay long.

SP.SPEAKER: LABRADORE.
SP.P: Goodsh day to you—I am going to strike a bargain with a friend's wife. [Exit LABRADORE.

SP.SPEAKER: COQUIN.
SP.P: And I with an acquaintance, daughter. [Throws off his disguise.] Ha, ma petite chere. [Kissing her.] By gar, de maladie, de sickness do so well—I will be sick all my life—'dat is love sick.

SP.SPEAKER: DAUGHTER.
SP.P: And in truth the false priest pash so pleasant, that I don't care how soon I see the real one.

SP.SPEAKER: COQUIN.
SP.P: Allons donc——now for de marriage tout est pret—adieu, Monsieur Labradore—Ah! my dear green box—and my dear littel wife—littel—by gar, I make you one great lady in a few month. [Exeunt running.

DIV2.HEAD: SCENE II.
DIV2.STAGE: A large Room, leading into several others; a Pair of large folding Doors in the Back.
Enter Lord RENTLESS, leading in Miss UNIFORM, who follows with reluctance.

SP.SPEAKER: LORD.
SP.P: My dear Miss Uniform, there is not the least occa∣sion to be alarmed. Here's no danger in being seen here. People of the first fashion visit their acquaint∣ance at this hotel, and you may rely upon me, my ho∣nour.

SP.SPEAKER: MISS.
SP.P: Ah! my Lord, but if you should forget your honour, what would become of mine?

SP.SPEAKER: LORD.
SP.P: Oh! my charming apprehensive girl, believe me you are in perfect security; besides, I am a married man, and—

SP.SPEAKER: MISS.
SP.P: So much the more dangerous. You married men have a privilege from your situation.

SP.SPEAKER: LORD.
SP.P: Yes, but then you know we are always to be trust∣ed; for we are suppos'd at least to be attach'd to our wives.

SP.SPEAKER: MISS.
SP.P: But what would be suppos'd, if we re seen thus to∣gether?

SP.SPEAKER: LORD.
SP.P: Why, to confess the truth, it was upon that account that I took the tender liberty of requesting a meeting at this hotel, merely on that account; as public walks are exposed; prudes censorious; and the world too apt to put wrong constructions on the best designs.

SP.SPEAKER: MISS.
SP.P: Yes; but if any of the world should happen to ob∣serve us here, and put wrong constructions.

SP.SPEAKER: LORD.
SP.P: Oh, impossible! I assure you, not a creature ever pre∣sumes—

SP.SPEAKER: MISS.
SP.P: Bless me! here's somebody presuming, I am certain.

SP.SPEAKER: LORD.
SP.P: Egad, so there is. Here, here, retire this way.
SP.STAGE: [They open a door on one side the stage and retire.

SP.SPEAKER: LABRADORE.
SP.P: Waiter, wash there nobody enquiring for me, eh?

SP.SPEAKER: WAITER.
SP.P: Ye, ye, yes Sir! there was a servant asking for a lit∣tel swarthy-looking gentleman this morning.

SP.SPEAKER: LABRADORE.
SP.P: Umph! a servant! No no, I wash mean a ladysh, a fine womansh.

SP.SPEAKER: WAITER.
SP.P: A fine woman enquiring for you, Sir!

DIV2.STAGE: Enter two Chairmen, bringing in a Chair—curtains drawn—they set it down.

SP.SPEAKER: LABRADORE.
SP.P: Yesh, for me. Get along with your impertinence,
[Approaching the chair.] Let me take thish sweet jewel, out of the littel black case.

SP.SPEAKER: LADY.
SP.P: Sure, Mr. Labradore, you can't suppose I mean to come out of my chair.

SP.SPEAKER: LABRADORE.
SP.P: Oh, yesh, my Ladysh! Dat ish the more prudent.

SP.SPEAKER: LADY.
SP.P: Well, well, I must not hesitate now.
[After getting out.] Lord, what an awkward situation I have brought myself into! I am terrified at the od∣dity of it.

SP.SPEAKER: LABRADORE.
SP.P: Ah! my dear ladysh, you wash so punctual.

SP.SPEAKER: LADY.
SP.P: Yes, Mr. Labradore; as I had promis'd, I would not break my word.

SP.SPEAKER: LABRADORE.
SP.P: Oh! it would have been a great shin.

SP.SPEAKER: LADY.
SP.P: And you would sooner forgive any other, I believe. I fancy I know the state of your vanity in that particu∣lar, to a scruple.

SP.SPEAKER: LABRADORE.
SP.P: Yesh; I have very few scruples indeed—

SP.SPEAKER: LADY.
SP.P: You have a great deal of wit, Mr. Labradore.

SP.SPEAKER: LABRADORE.
SP.P: I think I wash shine in conversation—I was tole∣rable brilliant; heh, my dear Ladyships:

SP.SPEAKER: LADY.
SP.P: Yes, but your brilliancy, you know was stolen from me.

SP.SPEAKER: LABRADORE.
SP.P: Then I shall restore it to the right owner—Ah, the pretty rogues? Christian me, but I must have the pleasure of putting them on.

SP.SPEAKER: LADY.
SP.P: Hold Sir—the bounds of decorum demand a cer∣tain attention, and require that one should observe—

SP.SPEAKER: LABRADORE.
SP.P: Yesh; that one should observe—

SP.SPEAKER: LADY.
SP.P: I wish I was well rid of the fellow—how odious, and impertinent he is!

SP.SPEAKER: LABRADORE.
SP.P: What does her kind Ladyship say?

SP.SPEAKER: LADY.
SP.P: I say one must not entirely forget the—

SP.SPEAKER: LABRADORE.
SP.P: The bracelets—which I am just going to place upon your fair hand—come my dear ladish. [Trying them on.

SP.SPEAKER: LADY.
SP.P: Well, Mr. Labradore, since you are determin'd to be so gallant, as to indulge me with my own property a∣gain, be assur'd I shall not fail to insist on my Lord's re∣paying this piece of generosity hereafter.

SP.SPEAKER: LABRADORE.
SP.P: Hereafter—lordsh, how can you be so wicked—what have we to do but with the present?

SP.SPEAKER: LADY
SP.P: Oh, fye! I must leave you—my Lord expects to find me at home.

SP.SPEAKER: LABRADORE.
SP.P: So much the better, then he will never look for you abroad—Come, one token of gratitude.

SP.SPEAKER: LADY.
SP.P: For Heaven's sake, Sir, What can you mean? Imper∣tinent—I think this is the way out, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: LABRADORE.
SP.P: I believe it is—and I think I am out enough al∣ready.

SP.SPEAKER: LADY.
SP.P: Defend me! here's company just coming in.

SP.SPEAKER: LABRADORE.
SP.P: This way, my dear Ladyship.

DIV2.STAGE: [They open a door on the opposite side of the stage, and retire.]
Re-enter Lord RENTLESS, and Miss UNIFORM.

SP.SPEAKER: LORD.
SP.P: Come, my dear Miss Uniform, we may return, the coast is quite clear.

SP.SPEAKER: MISS.
SP.P: Indeed, my Lord, I am so frightened, I scarce know what I am about—who could those people be?

SP.SPEAKER: LORD.
SP.P: What is it to us who they were? Don't trouble your∣self about them—it can be no business of ours. Come, my dear Miss Uniform; do not always refuse to listen to a man who adores you.

SP.SPEAKER: MISS.
SP.P: Indeed I cannot listen to any thing now—I am so flurried and discompos'd—and—and—

SP.SPEAKER: LORD.
SP.P: Believe me, my love, you are perfectly safe. Come, come, throw aside this trifling coquetry.

SP.SPEAKER: MISS.
SP.P: Pray, my Lord, let me go—Indeed I won't stay.

SP.SPEAKER: LORD.
SP.P: For Heaven's-sake, my angel! stop but for a moment.

SP.SPEAKER: ALDERMAN.
SP.P: Don't stop me I say. I must speak with him about business of the regiment.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord and Miss together.
SP.P: Zounds, your father—Here—there—any where.

DIV2.STAGE: [Run about to different parts of the stage, finding the door they came out from fast.]

SP.SPEAKER: ALDERMAN.
SP.P: With a lady! What care I for his being with a lady. Heh, my Lord [advancing jocularly.] What's a lady to me, hah?

DIV2.STAGE: [My Lord attempts to receive the Alderman, Miss bursts open the door, where my Lady and Labradore are concealed.]

SP.SPEAKER: LORD.
SP.P: Confusion!

SP.SPEAKER: ALDERMAN.
SP.P: Heaven's! my daughter.

SP.SPEAKER: LORD.
SP.P: The devil! my wife—

SP.SPEAKER: ALDERMAN.
SP.P: I think, my Lord, you seem to have met more company than you expected.

SP.SPEAKER: LADY.
SP.P: It might probably be as well, Mr. Alderman, if some people minded their own business, and kept their daugh∣ters at home.

SP.SPEAKER: ALDERMAN.
SP.P: Yes, my Lady, and their wives too.

SP.SPEAKER: MISS.
SP.P: I think her Ladyship might at least have been quiet.

SP.SPEAKER: ALDERMAN.
SP.P: Zounds! child, will you be quiet—don't make more stir than you have done.

SP.SPEAKER: LORD.
