SP.P: Indeed, Mr. Uniform, I hope you do not imagine that any improper motive; that is, that any view—that—that was not.

SP.SPEAKER: ALDERMAN.
SP.P: Disband me, my Lord; but I know my duty to my su∣perior officer, or else I'd sound such an alarm—But come along, child, you shall march without beat of drum.
SP.STAGE: [Exeunt Alderman and Miss, flouncing by my Lady.

SP.SPEAKER: LADY.
SP.P: Impertinent! the taste that some people have is so ex∣traordinary.

SP.SPEAKER: LORD.
SP.P: I am entirely of your Ladyship's opinion.

SP.SPEAKER: LADY.
SP.P: Intolerable, my Lord—

SP.SPEAKER: LORD.
SP.P: I am surprised that you should think so, my Lady, who seem such a friend to toleration, and as much attached to one persuasion as another.

SP.SPEAKER: LABRADORE.
SP.P: Upon my wordsh, I hopesh that you wash not offended at the littel appearance, for I shwear by Jerusalem—

SP.SPEAKER: LORD.
SP.P: There's no occasion, Mr. Labradore, to go half so far.

SP.SPEAKER: LABRADORE.
SP.P: But I say my Lordsh, I should be shorry if you should be displeas'd with my Ladish.

SP.SPEAKER: LADY.
SP.P: Lord, Sir! How can you be so absurd?

SP.SPEAKER: LORD.
SP.P: Very true, my Lady—How could you fancy, Mr. La∣bradore, I should be angry about such a subject?

SP.SPEAKER: LABRADORE.
SP.P: Hoh! hoh! Well, if you wash not angry, then there was no occasion to be shorry—except for the bracelets. [Aside.] This it is to be so damn'd generous.

SP.SPEAKER: LADY.
SP.P: But courage, Mr. Labradore; you know I've promis'd you for hereafter.

SP.SPEAKER: LABRADORE.
SP.P: Oh! my Ladyship, thoshe distant securities wash very uncertainsh. I am glad to get off so well.

SP.SPEAKER: LORD.
SP.P: Your friend Mr. Labradore seems to have experienc'd a disappointment rather severe—

SP.SPEAKER: LADY.
SP.P: My friend, my Lord! don't mention the odious wretch, I beg of you—I was only—

SP.SPEAKER: LORD.
SP.P: Nay, pray don't distress yourself; there is no occasion to invent an excuse for such a fellow.

SP.SPEAKER: LADY.
SP.P: Certainly, my Lord - He is not worth telling a story a∣bout. I saw the creature walking in the street, and set him down here on business—When he would have me step in, forsooth, to see the apartments; and as your Lord∣ship is under some obligations—

SP.SPEAKER: LORD.
SP.P: True, and probably he would have no objection to add to them.

SP.SPEAKER: LADY.
SP.P: Perhaps not; for thinking I wanted ornaments he has been very attentive to supply the deficiency—Look you, my Lord, how surprisingly beautiful. [Shewing the bracelets.

SP.SPEAKER: LORD.
SP.P: Ha! Surprising indeed! Ha, ha, ha, it was only a little conceit of mine, I thought you would find out where I had hid them.

SP.SPEAKER: LADY.
SP.P: Yes, your Lordship is happy in conceits. I suppose the hiding Miss Uniform was one of them—You knew I should find that out too,

SP.SPEAKER: LORD.
SP.P: No, no, no!—Not so—She beckon'd to me from her carriage, as I was coming this way; and out of a frolic, I would shew her the elegance of the hotel—Ha! ha! ha! Egad, these city Misses are such imitators of their betters, they are always running in one's way—A-propos, my La∣dy, is your chair in waiting? It would probably be as well, after this little bruit, to be at home this evening.

SP.SPEAKER: LADY.
SP.P: By no means, my Lord, one would not do any thing singular this evening at least—any particular regularity would be noticed; so I shall call in at a few places, plague three or four intimate friends, and retire to my own apart∣ment, without disturbing your Lordship.

SP.SPEAKER: LORD.
SP.P: Your Ladyship is too kind. You know I never dispute any of your wishes: therefore I'll e'en go home, and think of settling Charles happily in marriage. The honour of your Ladyship's hand. Shall I place the jewels on your Ladyship's dressing table.

SP.SPEAKER: LADY.
SP.P:
By no means, my Lord—for if you should have ano∣ther conceit, and happen to hide them, I may perhaps not happen to find them out again; but as your Lordship seems conversant with all the doors in this house, will you
be so good as to shew me the direct way out; for should we make another mistake, and be surprised together, it would absolutely ruin one among one's acquaintances.

DIV2.HEAD: ACT V. SCENE I.
DIV2.STAGE: A Dressing-Room belonging to General Probe. Suits of Clothes, &c. laying about. A Table and Chocolate upon it. Servant brushing and putting on his Coat.

SP.SPEAKER: PROBE.
SP.P: SO, there are no letters or messages, you say, come from my sister, Lady Rentless, during my absence?

SP.SPEAKER: SERVANT.
SP.P: None, General—there was a card for her Ladyship's public breakfast yesterday, but as you were not in town it was taken back.

SP.SPEAKER: PROBE.
SP.P: Well, well, be quick. You are as long making me up as an old dowager on a birth day.

SP.SPEAKER: SERVANT.
SP.P: One more brush, Sir, and you are finished. Oh, I had forgot—the groom has been here this morning, to say that Noble is lame.

SP.SPEAKER: PROBE.
SP.P: How! Why how could that horse be lame?

SP.SPEAKER: SERVANT.
SP.P: Indeed, Sir, I can't tell how.

SP.SPEAKER: PROBE.
SP.P:
No! Don't you know I always will know how every
thing happens? Go tell the groom to take care of him; and do you take care to bring me a good account of it.

Thank God, all the reviews are over for this year—and a pretty dance I have had—crost the Thames fifteen times out of sport—charg'd thro' twenty thickets for diver∣sion, and gallopp'd over Chatham barracks to take a fly∣ing inspection.—But now for my sister, to enquire into her family regulations since I left town—I suppose Charles's marriage is all settled, and I have only just to step in to eat some wedding cake, and see whether the bride blushes on the occasion.

DIV2.STAGE: Enter TRUSTY, in a great hurry.

SP.SPEAKER: TRUSTY.
SP.P: Oh, General Probe! I was afraid you were not got home yet—but I hurried to tell you—

SP.SPEAKER: PROBE.
SP.P: To tell me what?

SP.SPEAKER: TRUSTY.
SP.P: Lord, Sir! such things have happen'd—

SP.SPEAKER: PROBE.
SP.P: Happen'd! When? how?

SP.SPEAKER: TRUSTY.
SP.P: Oh, Sir! the Lord knows how—

SP.SPEAKER: PROBE.
SP.P: Very well—But how shall I know how, unless you inform me?

SP.SPEAKER: TRUSTY.
SP.P: Why, General, you shall hear—Yesterday evening, my master, the alderman, went out of his shop to get or∣ders—regimental ones I mean—

SP.SPEAKER: PROBE.
SP.P: Ah, Trusty, I always told you, that orderly plan of his would produce nothing but confusion—But why tell me this nonsense?

SP.SPEAKER: TRUSTY.
SP.P: Because I thought you were the only person in the world to make it out.

SP.SPEAKER: PROBE.
SP.P: Well then, be quick.

SP.SPEAKER: TRUSTY.
SP.P: So, Sir, all of a sudden, home comes he with young Miss, his daughter (who, to say the truth, is as fanciful as himself) under his arm—there, Madam, says he, push∣ing her into the room, I shall put you under arrest—Lord, papa, says she, I won't submit to such treatment—I'll have a court-martial on my conduct.

SP.SPEAKER: PROBE.
SP.P: Very spirited, i'faith—But what is this for?

SP.SPEAKER: TRUSTY.
SP.P: Why, Sir—(I hope nobody will hear us)—I under∣stand that my master, not finding my Lord at home, went to a hotel in pursuit of him, and there he caught his Lord∣ship and Miss together.

SP.SPEAKER: PROBE.
SP.P: How! But I hope nothing amiss had happen'd?

SP.SPEAKER: TRUSTY.
SP.P: No, no, his Lordship's schemes were defeated.

SP.SPEAKER: PROBE.
SP.P: Schemes! How could my Lord even imagine such a violation of delicacy, especially when he has the honour to be married to my sister.

SP.SPEAKER: TRUSTY.
SP.P: Lord, General! he minds nobody's sister—beside, begging your pardon, they say her Ladyship minds as little as he does.

SP.SPEAKER: PROBE.
SP.P: What! how! Dissipation on all sides!

SP.SPEAKER: TRUSTY.
SP.P: Yes, yes, it has made a fine confusion in the family. And it is whisper'd too, that my Lord has not been over scrupulous in the management of his ward's affairs—great deficiencies I hear.

SP.SPEAKER: PROBE.
SP.P:
You astonish me! But how again? Indeed certain
monies were left in his power to lay out for Charles's advantage—

SP.SPEAKER: TRUSTY.
SP.P: Aye, aye, he has laid them out for somebody's advan∣tage.

SP.SPEAKER: PROBE.
SP.P: And there were estates to be sold to pay off some incum∣brances—

SP.SPEAKER: TRUSTY.
SP.P: Instead of which, I fear, the incumbrances have encrea∣sed.

SP.SPEAKER: PROBE.
SP.P: It can't happen, I tell you—it must be utterly impos∣sible, that a peer of this country, whose honour is his oath, can condescend to break through a solemn engage∣ment on any account whatever.

SP.SPEAKER: TRUSTY.
SP.P: It should be impossible, General—but great men get over difficulties—However, I must now hurry home to my master—he talks of speaking to this Lord in an ho∣nourable way too—the devil take such honour, I say.

SP.SPEAKER: PROBE.
SP.P: I believe his honour had better be quiet.

SP.SPEAKER: TRUSTY.
SP.P: I hope you'll excuse me—but I thought it right to in∣form you of every thing I knew for the credit of your family, as well as our own.

SP.SPEAKER: PROBE.
SP.P: Thank you, honest Trusty, the families are equally oblig'd to you.

SP.SPEAKER: TRUSTY.
SP.P: Your servant, General. [Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: PROBE.
SP.P: Your servant, Trusty.—I am determin'd to dive deep into the business: for tho' I don't know how all this could possibly happen, yet some how or other it is a kind of thing that I don't know how to make any thing of. [Exit.

DIV2.HEAD: SCENE II.
DIV2.STAGE: A Room in Lord Rentless's House.
Enter Sir ANDREW hastily, with Papers in his Hand, CHARLES following.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLES.
SP.P: But, Sir Andrew—

SP.SPEAKER: SIR ANDREW.
SP.P: But, Mr.—

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLES.
SP.P: I am sure you will find yourself mistaken.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR ANDREW.
SP.P: But I am sure I never can be mistaken—What! attempt to make me believe you were possessed of an ample for∣tune, large estate, and an unencumber'd property; and here I find, from my lawyer, that the very reverse of all this—

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLES.
SP.P: I don't understand what you mean, Sir Andrew—I hope you don't imagine—

SP.SPEAKER: SIR ANDREW.
SP.P: Oh, no, Sir, I imagine nothing—it's as plain as a pike staff, and as legible as these papers in my hand.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLES.
SP.P: You'll excuse the warmth of my expressions, Sir An∣drew: but you must give me leave to inform you, that I did not expect such treatment from your hands.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR ANDREW.
SP.P: Nor I from yours—but I beg pardon—I suppose it's one of the fashionable methods of treating country gentlemen—tho', Sir, I will say, that—But it's all very well.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLES.
SP.P: I beg you'll explain yourself, Sir Andrew.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR ANDREW.
SP.P: It's done in an instant—But no matter, I'll defer it to another opportunity.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLES.
SP.P: Sir Andrew, I must insist upon immediate—

SP.SPEAKER: SIR ANDREW.
SP.P: To be sure, Sir. I am your most obedient humble servant. Sir, I shall take the liberty of setting off for the country immediately, and leave all these high-bred manners, and maxims of polite life, behind me. Sir, your very humble servant. [Going.

SP.SPEAKER: HARRIOT.
SP.P: My dear papa, here is the charmingest present come home that Charles has sent me. You must come and look at it.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR ANDREW.
SP.P: Ah! it may go back again, as I intend to do. So order your things to be packed up directly, as I shall set out in half an hour at farthest for Acron Hall.

SP.SPEAKER: HARRIOT.
SP.P: Sir!

SP.SPEAKER: SIR ANDREW.
SP.P: Don't attempt to dissuade me, I say. Don't you en∣deavour to alter my resolution; but that's impossible, so you may say what you please.

SP.SPEAKER: HARRIOT.
SP.P: Heavens, my dear Sir! you alarm me to death. Pray, Sir, explain—Do, Charles, tell me the occasion of this sudden alteration.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLES.
SP.P: Oh, Harriot! I scarce know myself. But some idea that your father seems to ntertain that I have deceived him.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR ANDREW.
SP.P: And so you have, most monstrously—No; I beg par∣don, you have not. No man can, that I will say.

SP.SPEAKER: HARRIOT.
SP.P: Pray, for Heaven's sake, my dear father, explain the reason, and make me wretched, if I am to be so, at once.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR ANDREW.
SP.P: Why, child, you know when I consented to this match of yours, that gentleman there informed me of his being immediately to possess a very large property, which I very readily believed, imagining that no person of character could—But I beg pardon. And now I find the estate next to nothing, the whole of it being disposed of, to pay off the numerous debts that were upon it.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLES.
SP.P: Impossible!

SP.SPEAKER: SIR ANDREW.
SP.P: Very probable, I should think; for I have the accounts here in my hand, all distinctly written and vouched by your guardian.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLES.
SP.P: Vouched by my guardian! Amazement! But assure yourself, Sir, that I retain a proper sense of your suspi∣cions, which time will shew you to be ill founded.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR ANDREW.
SP.P: Time! Yes, yes, there will be time enough in all conscience; for I shall depart immediately, and leave you all the time you can wish. So come, child, take your leave of Lady Rentless, and my Lord too, who, I sup∣pose, will be the first to laugh at my scruples.

SP.SPEAKER: HARRIOT.
SP.P: My dear Sir, let me beg—let me entreat—

SP.SPEAKER: SIR ANDREW.
SP.P: Don't entreat me, I say. I am resolved upon going; and though I hate obstinacy, I never alter a first inten∣tion. So come along.

SP.SPEAKER: HARRIOT.
SP.P: [In tears.] O Heavens!

SP.SPEAKER: SIR ANDREW.
SP.P:
Psha, child. Shew a proper sense of the dignity of your character and a firmness. If I stay here much longer, I shall yield. [Aside.] 'Tis want of integrity,
not fortune we resent. So come along, child, and prove yourself the daughter of Sir Andrew Acorn.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLES.
SP.P: Wretched as I am, my resentment overcomes every other passion. To be charged with imposition, and that by the father of the person I adore—Distracting thought! But I will discover the cause of his suspicions, or not exist under the weight of them. [Exit.

DIV2.HEAD: SCENE III.
DIV2.STAGE: A Room in the Alderman's House.
Breakfast finished; Uniform sitting with his Head upon his Hand, ruminating; she looking down and playing upon her Fingers.

SP.SPEAKER: ALDERMAN.
SP.P: [Recovering from his reverie.] A plague upon all daugh∣ters, I say, with all my heart!

SP.SPEAKER: MISS.
SP.P: Lud, papa, you make so much to do about nothing.

SP.SPEAKER: ALDERMAN.
SP.P: Nothing, do you call it, to be found with a man alone!

SP.SPEAKER: MISS.
SP.P: Alone! Why, I am sure there was company enough.

SP.SPEAKER: ALDERMAN.
SP.P: Ah, a pretty company truly! Have you forgot what a nice thing a lady's honour is, and that a breath may destroy reputation?

SP.SPEAKER: MISS.
SP.P: Then what signifies talking so much about it. I re∣peat it; the rencontre was quite accidental.

SP.SPEAKER: ALDERMAN.
SP.P: Don't tell a—A soldier though should never give the lie—But no matter. I'll soon have another ren∣contre; fire and faggot but I will.

SP.SPEAKER: MISS.
SP.P: Dear, papa, you are grown so passionate since you went into the army, and have got such a habit of swear∣ing, that you terrify one to death.

SP.SPEAKER: ALDERMAN.
SP.P: Damnation! but what's that to you. I believe, I shan't easily frighten you, Miss Brazen.

SP.SPEAKER: WINNI.
SP.P: Dear-a-me, dear-a-me, your honour! Here's Deputy Dowlass, and two or three more Aldermen come to en∣quire after your accident.

SP.SPEAKER: ALDERMAN.
SP.P: Aye; there it is. The murder is all out.

SP.SPEAKER: WINNI.
SP.P: Yes; they say you were run through the body by a nobleman, and drove away in a hearse that was passing by at the time.

SP.SPEAKER: TRUSTY.
SP.P: [Hastily.] Oh, Sir! Here's the devil to pay. A general from the artillery ground has sent to know, if the family would have them bury you with military honours, and fire over your grave.

SP.SPEAKER: ALDERMAN.
SP.P: Zounds! shut up the doors and bury me alive. There, Miss, you see what your vagaries have come to. But if I live and do well, I'll cut somebody's throat—cannonade me but I will.

SP.SPEAKER: MISS.
SP.P: Gracious! my dear papa.

SP.SPEAKER: ALDERMAN.
SP.P: Don't dear me. Blood and wounds, guns and gun∣powder!

SP.SPEAKER: WINNI.
SP.P: Alack! alack! we shall be all blown up for ever. Pray, Sir, forget your honour, and think of the shop. The poor shop! Oh! Oh!

SP.SPEAKER: ALDERMAN.
SP.P: Damn the shop. Trusty, where are my pistols? Bayonet me, but I've a good mind to meet him with a fusee, and make sure of him at once.

SP.SPEAKER: TRUSTY.
SP.P: Heavens, Sir! What would become of you if you should commit murder in cold blood? Justice would—

SP.SPEAKER: ALDERMAN.
SP.P: Justice be hanged. What has justice to do with honour? Is n't it proper that all soldiers should fight once in their lives to establish their fame. Oh, here are my trumpeters. [Taking down his pistols.

SP.SPEAKER: MISS.
SP.P: Dear Sir, think only of the danger of the times, and that your country has a right to your assistance.

SP.SPEAKER: ALDERMAN.
SP.P: Let my country for once go without.

SP.SPEAKER: WINNI.
SP.P: Pray, your honour, relent.

SP.SPEAKER: ALDERMAN.
SP.P: [Examining his pistols and not regarding them.] Flint and steel.

SP.SPEAKER: TRUSTY.
SP.P: Consider, Sir.—Allow yourself one short interval.

SP.SPEAKER: ALDERMAN.
SP.P: [Stepping over the ground.] Twelve paces only, and the first shot.

SP.SPEAKER: WINNI.
SP.P: [Falling on her knees.] O dear, sweet, good, kind, Sir, pray don't. Have mercy.

SP.SPEAKER: ALDERMAN.
SP.P: [Without regarding her.] Fire to an inch, and lay odds that I hit him. May I never be mustered, if I shan't be an example to the whole army. [Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: MISS.
SP.P: [Following her father.] Lord, papa, we shall be all put in the newspapers.

SP.SPEAKER: TRUSTY.
SP.P: [Following.] Yes; and some of us in the Gazett.

SP.SPEAKER: WINNI.
SP.P: [Following.] Oh, the shop! the poor shop! [Exeunt.

DIV2.HEAD: SCENE IV.
DIV2.STAGE: An Anti-Room in Lord Rentless's House.

SP.SPEAKER: PROBE.
SP.P: Well, now I shall certainly see how matters are. Trusty only supposes, that my Lord and my sister—Ah! I hate supposes, particularly about women. No, no, I dare say I shall find all within as happy—aye, as happy as a wedding can make them.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLES.
SP.P: O General! you are the person I most wished to meet. During your absence I have made such a discovery!

SP.SPEAKER: PROBE.
SP.P: Aye!—how!—where?

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLES.
SP.P: Yes, Sir, from being one of the most envied, I am now the most miserable of mankind.

SP.SPEAKER: PROBE.
SP.P: A very notable discovery, indeed.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLES.
SP.P: But I will at least revenge myself on the villain who has undone me. I beg pardon, General Probe, for join∣ing that name to a brother-in-law of yours. But Lord Rentless shall feel—

SP.SPEAKER: PROBE.
SP.P: Lord Rentless! Explain yourself.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLES.
SP.P:
The loss of fortune I could easily sustain; but to be lowered, sunk, degraded, in the eyes of those we most
esteem—O Sir, the distress of my mind is more than I can support.

SP.SPEAKER: PROBE.
SP.P: Compose yourself, my dear Charles. Let me know how, and what has happen'd to you, and assure yourself, that no ties of blood shall prevent me from fulfilling the duties of a man of honour.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLES.
SP.P: I know, General, all your goodness, and therefore scru∣ple not to inform you, that my Lord Rentless dishonour∣ably abusing the trust that was reposed in him, has sacri∣ficed my fortune to his own purposes, while my total ig∣norance of this transaction has made me appear the mean mercenary cheat that wanted to impose upon the honour, the generosity, the love—I cannot proceed further.

SP.SPEAKER: PROBE.
SP.P: There's my hand, boy, and if—

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLES.
SP.P: If, Sir—Can you suppose that I would dare to trifle with you? But as for Lord Rentless—

SP.SPEAKER: PROBE.
SP.P: Moderate your resentment—there yet may be mis∣takes, indeed I don't see how.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLES.
SP.P: Nor any honest man how a villain may proceed. But to lose every hope that mutual tenderness had fondly plan∣ned, to appear a low impostor to those whose generous bosoms had given me their unsuspecting friendship—'tis too much.

SP.SPEAKER: PROBE.
SP.P: I will set all things to rights. Every thing shall be turn'd topsy turvey, and that's the way to come at the truth.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLES.
SP.P: O Sir! your Goodness is too late. Sir Andrew sup∣posing me unworthy, is this instant setting off for the country; but injuries like mine cannot be forgiven, and I must have the only satisfaction that is left.

SP.SPEAKER: PROBE.
SP.P: So you shall—so you shall—but—

DIV2.STAGE: A Brace of Horse Pistols under his Arm, crosses the Stage without seeing them.

SP.SPEAKER: ALDERMAN.
SP.P: Points of honour must be determin'd immediately Sir, your pardon—Charles, your obedient—Lord Rentless within? Alone, heh? A small thing has happen'd—you understand me—an affront—pistols—satisfaction—good by'e to you. [Going.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLES.
SP.P: Alderman Uniform, one word by your leave. Has any thing happen'd betwixt you and Lord Rentless?

SP.SPEAKER: ALDERMAN.
SP.P: Happen'd—but—but I say little—Reports will get abroad tho'—You'll excuse my mentioning any thing; but I fancy the world will say, the affront offer'd to my daughter—Mum, I'm silent—I wish you good morning, gentlemen. [Going on the other side.

SP.SPEAKER: PROBE.
SP.P: How, Sir! Having some interest in Lord Rentless's con∣duct, permit me to ask you if his Lordship has dar'd to offer an affront to your daughter?

SP.SPEAKER: ALDERMAN.
SP.P: Affront! pistol me—but no matter—no man shall presume to offer any thing, to any part of my family, while I wear a jacket.

SP.SPEAKER: PROBE.
SP.P: But say how can this have arisen?

SP.SPEAKER: ALDERMAN.
SP.P: How! death and fury! but any explanation would be dishonourable.

SP.SPEAKER: PROBE.
SP.P: What! an explanation dishonourable. Sir, let me tell you, that I believe I am full as old a soldier as you are; and that I hold a fair explanation as the first proof of courage; and searching things to the bottom, the best ar∣gument of a good understanding.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLES.
SP.P: Don't be too warm yourself, General.

SP.SPEAKER: ALDERMAN.
SP.P: General! Oh, oh—dress to the right.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLES.
SP.P: I have not the least doubt from my knowledge of Lord Rentless, that he is capable of any conduct whatever; and his designs upon this gentleman's family have been long notorious.

SP.SPEAKER: PROBE.
SP.P: How! Are you certain of that? What! affront my sister, and entertain designs.

SP.SPEAKER: ALDERMAN.
SP.P: Yes, against my daughter.

SP.SPEAKER: PROBE.
SP.P: Zounds! I'll pistol him myself upon the spot.

SP.SPEAKER: ALDERMAN.
SP.P: After I have done with him, that is.

SP.SPEAKER: PROBE.
SP.P: But does your daughter confirm this act?

SP.SPEAKER: ALDERMAN.
SP.P: No, she'll confirm nothing; but I don't mind that, I have proof sufficient, and if I had not—no matter—courage must be shewn, the army require it, and Alder∣man Uniform, in a good cause, would meet the devil.

SP.SPEAKER: PROBE.
SP.P: But, Alderman, if that's your military title, before you proceed, I would advise you to step home, and bring your daughter in your hand, for then our enquiries will be more regular, as she is the best person in the world to ex∣plain the mystery.

SP.SPEAKER: ALDERMAN.
SP.P: Ha! I'll take your advice, General; for when I know what has been done—why—then I shall know what to do. [Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: GENERAL.
SP.P: Come along, my dear boy—We'll go this instant, and make his Lordship clear up this business immediate∣ly, or I'll know why. [Exeunt.

DIV2.HEAD: SCENE V.

SP.SPEAKER: LADY.
SP.P: Well, but my dearest Harriot, can I possibly help it, that Charles's fortune should not prove so large as Sir Andrew might expect?

SP.SPEAKER: HARRIOT.
SP.P: Ah, Lady Rentless! can you be insensible to the an∣guish of my heart?

SP.SPEAKER: LADY.
SP.P: Poogh, poogh—My dear Harriot, you must not in∣dulge these idle complaints; you see that your father is prudent enough to prefer fortune to every other conside∣ration; and therefore you should act like a discreet girl, and follow his good example.

SP.SPEAKER: HARRIOT.
SP.P: How can your Ladyship trifle with sorrow like mine? Afflicted, as I cannot fail to be, I own, I hoped from your friendship, if not a remedy, at least an alleviation of my grief.

SP.SPEAKER: LADY.
SP.P:
Why so it will, my pretty sufferer—will it not be carried down again, with all due decorum, to Acorn Hall, to be consoled with the good natured reflections of maid∣en aunts, and the compliments of country cousins, there to enjoy a sober tête-à-tête with its papa, who is a plea∣sant—
I beg pardon, not altogether pleasant; but who knows the world, and contradicts nobody.

DIV2.STAGE: Enter Sir ANDREW, hastily, equipped for his journey.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR ANDREW.
SP.P: Well, child, I hope you are ready for our departure, and have said your civil things to Lady Rentless here?

SP.SPEAKER: LADY.
SP.P: Yes, Sir Andrew, we have been saying a great many civil things about you, I assure you.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR ANDREW.
SP.P: Always much oblig'd to your Ladyship, no doubt. I presume, my Lord is engag'd at the House; so would not think of taking gentlemen from the good of their coun∣try for mere ceremony—Hope, your Ladyship will speak for us; and so, child, we'll be her Ladyship's most obedient and—[Going.

SP.SPEAKER: PROBE.
SP.P: Why, hey! my old acquaintance, Sir Andrew! What! in such a hurry to be gone, when I have made all the haste I could to come to you! Sister! Lady Rentless! what is the meaning of all this? What! nobody an∣swer? And here's my little favourite too! [To Harriot.] Won't she tell me how all this is?

SP.SPEAKER: HARRIOT.
SP.P: Pray, General—I beg you will not—I cannot—

SP.SPEAKER: PROBE.
SP.P: Why, this is strange indeed! Beginning a wedding in tears! I have heard of their ending so—But, where's my Lord? I hope he can explain this to all our satisfac∣tions.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLES.
SP.P: Yes, and shall do it.

SP.SPEAKER: PROBE.
SP.P: Oh, my Lord! you are just come in time to answer us all, so, speak openly at once.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLES.
SP.P: No, my Lord, a word with you in private—

SP.SPEAKER: LORD.
SP.P: Why, devil take me, I can't speak in two places at the same time—that's more than any member can do, at least, gentlemen.

SP.SPEAKER: PROBE.
SP.P: Come, come, my Lord, pleasantry on some occasions might as well be laid aside. It is necessary that you should explain how it is that this young couple, whom I expected to find on the point of being united, seem to be separating for ever.

SP.SPEAKER: LORD.
SP.P: Separating, General! I profess, I do not comprehend you.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLES.
SP.P: My Lord, no evasions, if you please—but inform me by what means my fortune—

SP.SPEAKER: LORD.
SP.P: Your fortune! The devil!—Oh, I believe Sir An∣drew fully comprehends the state of that.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR ANDREW.
SP.P: Yes, yes, I believe we perfectly understand each other, and more than some people would wish. But I beg par∣don—I understand nothing.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLES.
SP.P: But I beg pardon, Sir Andrew—you understand too much. My Lord, my Lord, this must be unravell'd.

SP.SPEAKER: LORD.
SP.P: Oh, dear, nothing so easy. Had I my papers here, I could explain the whole in an instant.

SP.SPEAKER: LABRADORE.
SP.P: Oh! chursh upon that wicked Lorsh! I wash robb'd—I wash plunder'd—All the writings of hish estates that wash deposited—all gone—all losht!

SP.SPEAKER: PROBE.
SP.P: Robb'd of his writings! How is that possible! he's but a tenant for life.

SP.SPEAKER: LABRADORE.
SP.P: Devil take his life! I mean the security of the West-India property that wash to buy, and have paid large sums of money in advance.

SP.SPEAKER: PROBE.
SP.P: Ha! how was that?

SP.SPEAKER: LABRADORE.
SP.P: How! Why, my daughter is gone off with a cursed French Lord, and taken jewels, monies, and all my move∣ables along with them—Oh, my papers! my bonds! my deeds! Oh! Oh!

SP.SPEAKER: COQUIN.
SP.P: Ah! mon chere, papa, don't make so noise—here are de papiers dat Mademoiselle, your daughter, my wife give to me.

SP.SPEAKER: LABRADORE.
SP.P: Your wife!

SP.SPEAKER: COQIN.
SP.P: Yes, I am de French nobleman, and one of de goodsh short de poor sick Rabbi, dat your daughter married out of disinterested love.

SP.SPEAKER: LABRADORE.
SP.P: Disinterested love! Oh, the unnatural child! There never wash any such thing in our family. But give me the shweet parchments—let me embrash them once more. [Running to seize the papers.

SP.SPEAKER: COQUIN.
SP.P: Pardonnez moi—I have got great desire to under∣stand, and as I no speak de Englis much better as yourself, I will give to mon General to translate.

SP.SPEAKER: PROBE.
SP.P: [Spreading the parchments.] Hey day! Why, it will take me an age to get to the bottom of these. [Reading.] What's here! Charles Woodbine!

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLES.
SP.P: As I live, my name and title deeds!

SP.SPEAKER: LABRADORE.
SP.P: Your deedsh! Why, I never had any thing else for my monish.

SP.SPEAKER: ALDERMAN.
SP.P: Here we are, my Lord, daughter and co.—Now only think, my Lady.

SP.SPEAKER: LADY.
SP.P: Indeed, Mr. Alderman, I can think nothing about you.

SP.SPEAKER: LABRADORE
SP.P: But I repeat it, my Lorsh, my property that is gone.

SP.SPEAKER: ALDERMAN,
SP.P: But I say, my Lord, my daughter that is here.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLES.
SP.P: And I urge, my Lord, my character that has been aspersed.

SP.SPEAKER: LORD.
SP.P: A truce, gentlemen, for a moment, and I will explain myself. Though fashionable indulgencies may have led me into error, I hope I am above a deliberate falshood to conceal it. The deposit of Charles's deeds with Mr. Labradore, was merely to supply a temporary necessity▪ but he will find from my steward, that I had the means, as well as the intention, of restoring all his property unhurt, and Sir Andrew shall see this matter clearly, at least.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR ANDREW.
SP.P: Pray though, my Lord, do you in London call this taking care of your ward's affairs in the country—But there we know nothing.

SP.SPEAKER: PROBE.
SP.P: Yes, Sir Andrew, there is one thing known and agreed upon every where, that no extravagance or necessity should tempt a man to violate his trust. But let us not be unkind; something may be allowed to the incaution of youth, and something to the too general dissipation of the times.

SP.SPEAKER: ALDERMAN.
SP.P: Dress to the right; if the General thinks so, my daughter shall be angry no longer.

SP.SPEAKER: MISS.
SP.P: Dear, papa, I never was angry at all.

SP.SPEAKER: ALDERMAN.
SP.P: Hold your tongue, child, I say you was. Well, old Labradore, remember I told you, though you had got into the line, you might pay for promotion.

SP.SPEAKER: LABRADORE.
SP.P: Yesh, young Uniform; but I shall take the means to be repaid with interest immediately.

SP.SPEAKER: LADY.
SP.P: Nay, Mr. Labradore, remember our bargain was only for hereafter, and I'm sure my Lord will in proper time fulfil the engagement—but let me do one piece of imme∣diate justice. Come, Sir Andrew, with your consent I'll place this hand where I know it will be most valued. [Taking Harriot.] Poor thing! it shan't go into the country to enjoy a téte-à-tte with its papa.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR ANDREW.
SP.P: Charles, I have done you wrong; and it shall be the business of my life to do you justice—no, that's impos∣sible, so I won't undertake it; therefore, Harriot, do you make him all the recompence you can.

SP.SPEAKER: COQUIN.
SP.P: Let me now hope my Ladie will spoke to mon papa.

SP.SPEAKER: LABRADORE.
SP.P: I won't hear a wordsh.

SP.SPEAKER: LADY.
SP.P: Come, come, Mr. Labradore, there was a time when I could persuade you to any thing—even to the parting with your securities.

SP.SPEAKER: LORD.
SP.P: And as I have undertaken to replace their value, your resentment should subside.

SP.SPEAKER: LABRADORE.
SP.P: To be sure, my Lorsh, if I recover my monish, I shall think less to loosh my daughter; so, Mounsheer, presherve your principles, and you shall come and be one of the goodsh short.

SP.SPEAKER: ALDERMAN.
SP.P: And, Ephy, if you want to make your son a gentle∣man, put him on a jacket.

SP.SPEAKER: PROBE.
SP.P: Come, my friends, as harmony seems again restored, we will now retire to celebrate the union of this deserving couple; and at the same time let us reflect, that the pre∣sent rage for dissipation, by treating lightly all the serious engagements of life, is at once the bane of filial affection, parental tenderness, and nuptial love.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR ANDREW.
SP.P: Well said, my worthy friend, and should any here venture to dispute your assertions, I shall not hesitate to declare—But I beg pardon—I never contradict this company.
